revision.text:
{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission |nativename = ادارہ جوہری توانائی پاکستان |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |picture = PAEC logo.png |picture_width = |picture_caption = |formed = {{start date and age|1956}} |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = [[National Command Authority (Pakistan)]] (NCA) |jurisdiction = [[Government of Pakistan]] |headquarters = [[Islamabad Capital Territory]] |coordinates = |employees = Classified |budget = Classified |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = [[Muhammad Naeem (physicist)]] (Nuclear Scientist) |chief1_position = |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |agency_type = |parent_agency = [[Strategic Plans Division Force]], [[Pakistan Armed Forces]] |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |keydocument1= |website = http://www.paec.gov.pk/ }}
The '''Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission''' ('''PAEC'''; [[Urdu]]: {{Nastaliq|ادارہ جوہری توانائی پاکستان}}) is an [[:Category:Pakistan federal departments and agencies|independent]] [[Government of Pakistan|governmental authority]] and a [[Science and technology in Pakistan|scientific]] research institution, concerned with research and development of [[nuclear power]], promotion of [[Atomic physics|nuclear science]], [[energy conservation]] and the peaceful usage of [[nuclear technology]].<ref name="IAEA publications, PAEC direct">{{cite web|last1=Tahir|first1=Abdul Ghaffar|title=IAEA presentation on nuclear power by PAEC|url=http://www.iaea.org/NuclearPower/Downloadable/Meetings/2013/2013-10-01-10-04-TM-NPE/2.3.pakistan.pdf|publisher=IAEA publications, PAEC direct|accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="Australian Safeguards Office">{{cite web|last1=ASO|title=Nuclear Power in Pakistan|url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/Country-Profiles/Countries-O-S/Pakistan/|publisher=Australian Safeguards Office|accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref>
Since its establishment in 1956, the PAEC has overseen the extensive development of nuclear infrastructure to support the economical uplift of Pakistan by founding institutions that focus on development on [[food irradiation]] and on [[Nuclear medicine in Pakistan|nuclear medicine]] radiation therapy for [[cancer]] treatment.<ref name="PAEC Medical DIvision">{{cite web|last1=staff|title=Biomedical engineering at PAEC|url=http://www.paec.gov.pk/Medical/|publisher=PAEC Medical DIvision|accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="PAEC BIO Division">{{cite web|last1=et. al. staff developer|title=Agriculture and Biotechnology|url=http://www.paec.gov.pk/Agriculture/|publisher=PAEC BIO Division|accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref> The PAEC organizes conferences and directs research at the country's leading universities.<ref name="Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission ">{{cite web | title =PAEC and Summer College on Physics | work =International Nathiagali Summer College | publisher =Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission | url =http://www.paec.gov.pk/INSC/ }}</ref> Since the 1960s, the PAEC is also a scientific research partner and sponsor of [[European Organization for Nuclear Research]] (CERN), where Pakistani scientists have contributed to developing [[particle accelerator]]s and research on [[high-energy physics]].<ref name="CERN Courier">{{cite web|last1=Ahmad, DSc|first1=Ishfaq|title=CERN and Pakistan: a personal perspective|url=http://cerncourier.com/cws/article/cern/28934|publisher=CERN Courier|accessdate=4 November 2014|location=Switzerland|date=5 October 2003}}</ref> PAEC scientists regularly pay visits to CERN while taking part in projects led by CERN.<ref name="Express Tribune, 2014">{{cite news|last1=Editorial|title=Pakistan and CERN|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/769312/pakistan-and-cern-2/|accessdate=4 November 2014|agency=Express Tribune|publisher=Express Tribune, 2014|date=30 September 2014}}</ref>
In 2001, the PAEC was integrated with the [[National Command Authority (Pakistan)]] which is under the [[Prime Minister of Pakistan]].<ref name="Director-General of the Inter-Services Public Relations (ISPR)">{{cite web|last1=ISPR release|title=National Command Authority|url=https://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-nca_press_release_archive|publisher=[[Inter-Services Public Relations|Director-General of the Inter-Services Public Relations (ISPR)]]|accessdate=4 November 2014|date=5 September 2013}}</ref>
==Overview==
===Early history=== {{Main article|Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction|Project-706|Chagai-I|Chagai-II}} [[File:Chaghi Monument.JPG|thumbnail|Chaghi Monument, Islamabad Pakistan]] Following the [[Partition of India|partition]] of [[British Indian Empire]] by the United Kingdom in 1947, Pakistan emerged as a Muslim-dominated state.<ref name="Routledge Publications Co."/> The [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1947|turbulent]] nature of its emergence critically influenced the scientific development of the country.<ref name="Routledge Publications Co.">{{cite book|last1=Chakma|first1=Bhumitra|title=Pakistan's nuclear weapons|date=2009|publisher=Routledge Publications Co.|location=New York, [u.s.a]|isbn=1134132549|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XTbOO0gVgR0C&pg=PA11 |accessdate=5 November 2014|language=|format=google books|chapter=Phase I: 1954-71}}</ref>
The establishment of the [[Pakistan Council of Scientific and Industrial Research|Council of Scientific and Industrial Research]] (PCSIR) in 1951 began Pakistan's research on physical sciences.<ref name="Croom Helm">{{cite book|last1=Kapur|first1=Ashok|title=Pakistan's nuclear development|date=1987|publisher=Croom Helm|location=London|isbn=0709931018|pages=258|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xtMNAAAAQAAJ&dq=Pakistan%27s+Nuclear+Development+ashol&hl=en&sa=X&ei=3OhZVPq6I8SbigKG4IGwCg&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA|accessdate=5 November 2014}}</ref> In 1953, U.S. President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|Dwight Eisenhower]] announced the [[Atoms for Peace]] program, and of which Pakistan became its earliest partner.<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)">{{cite web|last1=NTI st.al. publishers' contributors|title=NTI archives: 1953-71|url=http://www.nti.org/media/pdfs/pakistan_nuclear.pdf?_=1316466791|publisher=Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)|accessdate=5 November 2014|location=United States.|pages=234|format=PDF}}</ref> Research at PAEC initially followed a strict non-weapon policy issued by then-[[Foreign Minister of Pakistan|Foreign Minister]] Sir [[Muhammad Zafarullah Khan|Sir Zafar-ulla Khan]].<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> In 1955, the [[Government of Pakistan|government]] established a committee of scientists to prepare [[nuclear power|nuclear energy]] plans and build an industrial nuclear infrastructure throughout the country.<ref name="Dr. Aqeel Khan of the Ryerson University and the Ryerson University Press ">{{cite web | last =Khan | first =Aqeel | title =Development of Nuclear Industry in Pakistan | work =Professor Aqeel Khan, professor of Political Science at the [[Ryerson University]] | publisher =Dr. Aqeel Khan of the Ryerson University and the Ryerson University Press | date =7 June 2001 | url =https://www.scribd.com/doc/9124256/A-short-research-paper-on-the-development-of-Pakistans-nuclear-program | accessdate =15 August 2011 }}</ref> As the Energy Council Act went into full effect, Prime minister [[Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy|Huseyn Suhrawardy]] established the Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission (PAEC) in March 1956.<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> Its first chair was [[Nazir Ahmed (physicist)|Nazir Ahmad]] – an [[Experimental physics|experimental physicist]].<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> Other members of the PAEC included Technical member [[Salimuzzaman Siddiqui]], an [[Organic chemistry|organic chemist]] at the [[University of Karachi]], and [[Raziuddin Siddiqui]], a [[Mathematical physics|mathematical physicist]] at the same university.<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> Together, they both took charge of the research and development directorates of the commission.<ref name="Dr. Aqeel Khan of the Ryerson University and the Ryerson University Press "/> In 1958, [[Abdus Salam]] of the [[University of the Punjab]] also joined the commission, along with [[Munir Ahmad Khan]] who initially lobbied for acquiring a [[pool-type reactor]] from the United States.<ref name="Dr. Aqeel Khan of the Ryerson University and the Ryerson University Press "/>
In 1958, PAEC Chairman Nazir Ahmad proposed to the [[Pakistan Industrial Development Corporation]] to build a heavy water production facility with production capacity of 50 kg of [[Deuterium|heavy water]] per day at [[Multan]], but this proposal was not acted on.<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> In 1960, [[Ishrat Hussain Usmani|I.H. Usmani]] was elevated as PAEC's second chair with the transfer of Nazir Ahmad at the [[Federal Bureau of Statistics]].<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> The [[Multan Heavy Water Production Facility|reactor]] was built in 1962, financed by local fertilizer companies.<ref name="Federation of Atomic Scientists">{{cite web|last1=FAS|title=Multan heavy water reactor|url=https://fas.org/nuke/guide/pakistan/facility/multan.htm|publisher=Federation of Atomic Scientists|accessdate=5 November 2014}}</ref> In 1964, PAEC established its first research institute, the [[Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology]] (PINSTECH), at [[Nilore]], and began negotiation for country's first commercial nuclear power plant to be built in [[Karachi]].<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> In 1965, the PAEC reached an agreement with [[Canadian General Electric]] to build a [[CANDU reactor]] in Karachi.<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> Financial investment for the [[Karachi Nuclear Power Plant|nuclear power plant]] in [[Karachi]] was provided by the [[Economic Coordination Committee]], and [[Edward Durell Stone]] was commissioned to oversee the architectural design of PINSTECH.<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> From 1965–71, the PAEC sent 600 scientists abroad for training in nuclear sciences.<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> in 1969, the [[United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority]], agreed to supply a small scale [[nuclear reprocessing]] plant, with the capacity to extract 360 grams of plutonium per year.<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> In 1973, the PAEC announced the discovery of large uranium deposits in [[Punjab]].<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/>
After India's decisive victory in the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971]], Pakistan retracted its non-weapon policy and the research and development of [[Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction|nuclear weapons]] began in 1972.<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)"/> PAEC's senior [[Nuclear engineering|nuclear engineer]] [[Munir Ahmad Khan]], who threw himself with full rigor for this task, was named as PAEC's third chair by [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]].<ref name="Quercus Co.">{{cite book|last1=Fox|first1=Liam|title=Rising Tides: Facing the Challenges of a New Era|date=2013|publisher=Quercus Co.|location=London [u.k]|isbn=1782067418|pages=2000|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NU2wAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA1967&dq=Munir+Ahmad+Khan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=rNpaVNn9BO2aigLUqoC4BA&ved=0CEkQuwUwBQ#v=onepage&q=Munir%20Ahmad%20Khan&f=true|accessdate=6 November 2014}}</ref> Work began on ingenious development of the [[nuclear fuel cycle]] infrastructure and nuclear weapons research in the 1970s.<ref name="Lancer Publ.">{{cite book|last1=Nanda|first1=Prakash|title=Rediscovering Asia : evolution of India's look-east policy|date=2003|publisher=Lancer Publ.|location=New Delhi|isbn=8170622972|edition=1st ed. in India}}</ref> Key research took place at PINSTECH, where scientists worked on weapon designs and eventual [[nuclear weapons testing]].<ref name="Printwise publications"/> The PAEC expanded the crash program with various laboratories, facilities, and directorates researching on developing and testing materials and components for [[Nuclear weapon design|bomb designs]], whilst it engineered plants and funded facilities for production of [[enriched uranium#highly enriched uranium|highly enriched uranium]] (HEU) and [[plutonium]].<ref name="Printwise publications"/> In 1976, the possible test sites were decided by the PAEC and construction on test sites were completed in 1979.<ref name="Printwise publications"/> In 1983, PAEC's efforts reached to a milestone when it had conducted a first [[Subcritical testing|subcritical test]] on a weapon design; such testing continued until the early 1990s under codename: [[Kirana-I]].<ref name="Printwise publications">{{cite book|last1=[Shahid-ur-Rehman]|title=Long road to Chagai|date=1999|publisher=Printwise publications|location=Islamabad|isbn=9789698500009}}</ref>
Following nuclear tests by India earlier in the month, on 28 May 1998, PAEC led the final preparations and conducted Pakistan's first [[List of nuclear weapons tests of Pakistan|nuclear tests]] (Codename: [[Chagai-I]]), which was followed by [[Chagai-II]] in [[Kharan Desert]] on 30 May 1998. In 2001, the PAEC's research was focused back to civilian and peaceful research with the establishment of the [[Pakistan National Command Authority|National Command Authority]] and the [[Pakistan Nuclear Regulatory Authority]].<ref name="Stanford University Press">{{cite book|last1=Khan|first1=Feroz Hassan|title=Eating grass the making of the Pakistani bomb|date=2012|publisher=Stanford University Press|location=Palo Alto California [u.s.a0|isbn=0804784809|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yGgrNAsKZjEC&printsec=frontcover&dq=eating+grass+pakistan+ISBN&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6dlaVOL9EKj1iQLWk4CoAg&ved=0CDUQuwUwAA#v=onepage&q=eating%20grass%20pakistan%20ISBN&f=false|accessdate=6 November 2014}}</ref>
===Research and education=== {{Main article|Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology|Nuclear Institute for Agriculture and Biology|Institute of Nuclear Medicine, Oncology and Radiotherapy}}
Since its establishment in 1956, the PAEC provided a conspicuous example of benefit of the [[Atomic Era|atomic-age]] technologies for the advancement of [[agriculture]], [[engineering]], [[biology]], and [[medicine]].<ref name="United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization">{{cite book|last1=UNESCO|title=UNESCO science report 2010|date=2010|publisher=United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|location=Paris|isbn=9231041320}}</ref><ref name="Transaction Publishers">{{cite book|last1=editor|first1=Karthika Sasikumar,|title=Organizational cultures and the management of nuclear technology political and military sociology|date=2012|publisher=Transaction Publishers|location=New Brunswick, N.J.|isbn=1412848946|url=https://www.google.com/search?q=pakistan+atomic+energy+commission+education&biw=939&bih=586&source=lnms&tbm=bks&sa=X&psj=1&ei=pWZcVPTvEoqrjAKd4YGgCw&ved=0CAwQ_AUoAQ|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> In 1960, the PAEC established its first [[Nuclear Medicine and Biology|nuclear medicines]] center for [[Cancer]] treatment at the [[Jinnah Medical College]] of the [[University of Karachi]]; the second Medical Isotope Institute was established at the [[Mayo Hospital]] of the [[King Edward Medical University, Lahore]].<ref name="The Nucleus">{{cite journal|last1=Khurshid|first1=S.J.|title=Nuclear Medical Centers of PAEC|journal=The Nucleus|date=15 July 2005|volume=42|issue=1-2|pages=93–96|url=http://www.thenucleuspak.org.pk/nucleus/pdf%20Special%20Issue%20Nucleus%2042%281-4%29/Nuclear%20Medical%20Centers%28ms607%29.pdf|accessdate=7 November 2014|publisher=The Nucleus|location=Islamabad, Pakistan|format=PDF|issn=0029-5698}}</ref> Physicians and medical researchers were provided with facilities for cancer diagnose and treatment by the PAEC's funding.<ref name="The Nucleus"/>
In 1960, the PAEC established its regional atomic research center in [[Lahore]], and a metallurgy center in Karachi in 1963.<ref name="Edward Elger Publication Co.">{{cite book|last1=Edited by Turpin Tim|last2=Krishna|first2=V.V.|title=Science, Technology policy, and Diffusion of Knowledge: Understanding the Dynamic System of Asia-Pacific|date=2007|publisher=Edward Elger Publication Co.|location=Massachusetts [u.s.a0|isbn=1781008515|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PxfSSRK9V-AC&pg=PA288&dq=pakistan+atomic+energy+commission+science&hl=en&sa=X&ei=72hcVJ2RIMrvigKuo4GQDQ&ved=0CEUQuwUwBA#v=onepage&q=pakistan%20atomic%20energy%20commission%20science&f=true|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> Another energy center was located in [[Dhaka]] where many scientists were educated.<ref name="Edward Elger Publication Co."/> In 1967, the PAEC founded the [[Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences|Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences]] which became one of the primary technical universities of the country. Many of the PAEC's scientists and engineers served in its faculty.<ref name="Edward Elger Publication Co."/> The PAEC supports its university-level physics program at the [[Government College University, Lahore]] where it awards fellowships to the students. The PAEC continues to promotes its program as "peaceful uses of atomic energy commenced for the benefit the scientific community as well as public."<ref name=ScholarlyEditions>{{cite book|last1=Acton|first1=Q. Ashton|title=Isotopes—Advances in Research and Applications|date=2013|publisher=ScholarlyEditions|location=Atlanta, GA, [u.s.a]|isbn=1481676989|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DMndGfA9xYwC&pg=PA260&dq=pakistan+atomic+energy+commission+science&hl=en&sa=X&ei=q4NcVPu2CKfuiALV5IG4AQ&ved=0CEIQuwUwAzgU#v=onepage&q=pakistan%20atomic%20energy%20commission%20science&f=true|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
About its promotion of education, senior scientist, [[Ishfaq Ahmad]] quoted: "the PAEC was responsible to send more than 600 scientists to the abroad.<ref name="Nuclear Threat Initiatives (NTI)" /> As of present, PAEC maintains its prestigious image, and is now noted as one of the largest [[Science and technology in Pakistan|science and technology]] institution of the country.<ref name="SCIENCE, Pakistan">{{cite web|last1=et. al. contributors|title=Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission|url=http://www.pakchem.net/2011/09/pakistan-atomic-energy-commission.html#.VFyFdWcubKc|publisher=SCIENCE, Pakistan|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> The PAEC supports research activities and learning programs at the [[International Centre for Theoretical Physics]] (ICTP), of which PAEC is also its organizer.<ref name=PakAtom>{{cite journal|last1=Khan|first1=Shahid Riaz|title=Investment in Research|journal=PakAtom|date=May 2013|url=http://www.sidnlps.org.pk/pictures/Pak%20Atom.pdf|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> Since 1974, the PAEC has been a key organizer and sponsor of the [[International Nathiagali Summer College on Physics and Contemporary Needs]] conference each and every year where scientists from all over the world are delegated to the country.<ref name="International Nathiagali Summer College on Physics & Contemporary Needs, Nathiagali, Pakistan">{{cite web|last1=INSC|title=International Nathiagali Summer College on Physics & Contemporary Needs, Nathiagali, Pakistan|url=http://www.paec.gov.pk/INSC/|publisher=International Nathiagali Summer College on Physics & Contemporary Needs, Nathiagali, Pakistan|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> The [[International Nathiagali Summer College on Physics and Contemporary Needs|science conference in Nathiagali]] provides the dissemination of the knowledge advancement in [[physics]], [[chemistry]], [[biology]], [[astronomy]], [[mathematics]], [[computer science]], [[logic]], and [[philosophy]].<ref name="International Nathiagali Summer College on Physics & Contemporary Needs, Nathiagali, Pakistan"/>
As the emphasis shifted towards concerns for the [[National Security Council (Pakistan)|national security]] interests, the PAEC's important projects were also initiated in this area.<ref name="Stanford University Press"/> Many of the notable scientists with international prestige have worked and affiliated with the PAEC.<ref name="Stanford University Press"/> With the establishment of [[Pakistan Nuclear Regulatory Authority]] (PNRA) and [[Pakistan National Command Authority|National Command Authority]], the PAEC focused has not shifted back to utilization of [[nuclear power]] on peaceful and industrial usage as well as continued the research in nuclear developments in terms of both peaceful and scientific use.<ref name="SCIENCE, Pakistan"/>
===Studies on expansion of nuclear power=== {{Main article|Nuclear power in Pakistan}}
As of current, the PAEC is held responsible for design preparation and proper operational function of the commercial [[Nuclear power in Pakistan|nuclear power plants]]. The PAEC provides lobby at the governmental level for the safe usage of the nuclear power sources; though the [[Nuclear safety and security|safety regulations]] and protections of the nuclear power facilities are managed by the [[Pakistan Nuclear Regulatory Authority|Nuclear Regulatory Authority]] (PNRA). Providing the policy guidance to the government, PAEC's studies envisions setting up power plants energy production with a capacity of ~8800[[Megawatt|MW]] by 2030.<ref name="The Nation, 2013">{{cite news|last1=APP|title=PAEC to produce 8800MW by 2030|url=http://nation.com.pk/business/24-Jan-2013/paec-to-produce-8800mw-by-2030|accessdate=7 November 2014|agency=The Nation|publisher=The Nation, 2013|date=2 June 2013}}</ref>
Under this policy, the [[Karachi Nuclear Power Complex|KANUPP]] power plants and [[Chashma Nuclear Power Plant|CHASHNUPP]] power plants are expanded and currently under construction under PAEC and PNRA.<ref name="PAEC Nuclear Power">{{cite web|last1=PAEC Nuclear Power|title=Nuclear Power|url=http://paec.gov.pk/NuclearPower/|publisher=PAEC Nuclear Power|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
==Constituent institutions==
{{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Nuclear Institute for Food and Agriculture]] * [[Nuclear Institute for Agriculture and Biology]] * [[National Institute for Biotechnology and Genetic Engineering]] * [[National Agricultural Research Centre]] * [[Hussain Ebrahim Jamal Research Institute of Chemistry]] * [[Institute of Nuclear Medicine, Oncology and Radiotherapy]] * [[National Centre for Physics]] * [[International Nathiagali Summer College on Physics]]
{{div col end}}
==PAEC partnership with CERN==
[[Pakistan]] has a long history of participating in an experiments and research undertaking with [[CERN]], and has a long tradition of wonderful [[physicists]] who are working around the world.<ref name="cerncourier.com">{{cite web | last =CERN | first =Conseil Européen pour la Recherche Nucléaire | authorlink =Conseil Européen pour la Recherche Nucléaire | title =CERN Courier: CERN and Pakistan: a personal perspective | work =CERN Courier | publisher =cerncourier.com | date =6 Oct 2003 | url =http://cerncourier.com/cws/article/cern/28934 | format =HTTP | accessdate =2011 }}</ref> Since the 1960s, Pakistan has been contributing and regularly participating in CERN's project, theoretical and nuclear experiments.<ref name="cerncourier.com"/> A prime example would be [[Abdus Salam]]; Salam was the first man to be accredited with all the collaboration with CERN which continues till the present when he convinced CERN to give Pakistan stacks of [[nuclear emulsion]] exposed for further study of [[pions]], [[kaons]] and [[antiprotons]] in the 1960s.<ref name="paki.in">http://paki.in/wtf/2008/09/11/pakistans-contribution-to-the-large-hadron-collider-lhc/</ref> Some theoretical physicists from Pakistan had the opportunity to work at CERN through short visits.<ref name="cerncourier.com"/> During the 1980s, some of the experimental physicists from Pakistan, specialising in the technique of [[Solid-state nuclear track detector|Solid State Nuclear Track Detectors]] (SSNTD), also benefited from CERN by exposing the stacks in the beam at the Super Proton Synchrotron (SPS).<ref name="cerncourier.com"/>
In 2005, CERN awarded PAEC with the ATLAS Supplier Award in 2005, in connection with manufacturing and fabrication of various equipment for CERN.<ref name="Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission's International Relations Directorate."/>
On 27 June 2011, PAEC and CERN reached an agreement for extending the technical cooperation with CERN's upcoming programmes.<ref name="Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission's International Relations Directorate.">{{cite web |last = PAEC |title = Pakistan and CERN signed agreement for Technical Cooperation |work = PAEC Public Relations and International Press Directorate |publisher = Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission's International Relations Directorate. |date = 27 June 2011 |url = http://www.paec.gov.pk/paec-news.htm#p-mj11-news7 |format = HTTP |accessdate = 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100609150503/http://www.paec.gov.pk/paec-news.htm#p-mj11-news7#p-mj11-news7 |archive-date = 9 June 2010 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> CERN's Director-General [[Rolf-Dieter Heuer]] personally paid a visit to Pakistan where he spoke for the need of importance of [[Science in Pakistan]] and importance of Germany's strategic alliance with Pakistan.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} The agreement was signed in order to extend an earlier agreement, which came into operation in 2003 between CERN and Pakistan for the supply of manufactured equipment for Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN along with placement of scientists and engineers from Pakistan to assist in the scientific programme of CERN.<ref name="Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission's International Relations Directorate."/>
With the efforts led by the PAEC, the CERN granted and made Pakistan as its associate member, on 22 June 2014— the first [[Asia]]n country and second Muslim country after [[Turkey]].<ref name="Dawn Newspapers, 2014">{{cite news|last1=From the Newspaper|first1=AFP|title=Pakistan granted Cern’s associate membership|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1114339|accessdate=11 November 2014|agency=Dawn Newspapers|publisher=Dawn Newspapers, 2014|date=22 June 2014}}</ref>
===PAEC contribution to Compact Muon Solenoid=== In 1997, [[Ishfaq Ahmad]]— chair of the PAEC— reached to CERN to sign a contract between PAEC and CERN after elaborate discussions an in-kind contribution worth one million Swiss francs for the construction of eight magnet supports for the [[Compact Muon Solenoid|CMS]] detector.<ref name="paki.in"/>
For [[Compact Muon Solenoid|CMS]], the PAEC built magnet feet and installed 320 Resistive Plate Chambers (RPC), as well as contributing to CMS computing. Several other mechanical components for ATLAS and for the LHC were also built by the PAEC.<ref name="Pakistan and CERN">{{cite news|title=Pakistan and CERN|url=http://international-relations.web.cern.ch/international-relations/nms/pakistan.html|accessdate=11 November 2014|agency=Pakistan and CERN}}</ref> It was PAEC's efforts that led the [[Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology|Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology]] (PINSTECH) with CERN's direct cooperation in the area of radioprotection.<ref name="Pakistan and CERN"/>
===PAEC support to Large Hadron Collider=== [[File:LHC.svg|thumb|left|200px|PAEC took participation in the development of [[Large Hadron Collider]].]]
In 2000, CERN signed another agreement which doubled the Pakistani contribution from one to two million Swiss francs. And with this new agreement Pakistan started construction of the resistive plate chambers required for the CMS [[muon]] system. While more recently, a protocol has been signed enhancing Pakistan’s total contribution to the [[LHC]] programme to $10 million. Pakistan with all these efforts is already hoping to become an observer state at CERN.<ref name="cerncourier.com"/><ref name="paki.in"/> In 2006 PAEC and CERN agreed on expanded cooperation, including contributions by PAEC valued at 5 million Swiss francs.<ref>[http://google.com/clic-meeting.web.cern.ch/clic-meeting/CTF3_Coordination_Mtg/MoU_Addenda/Protocole_CERN_Pakistan.pdf 2006 Protocol on CERN-PAEC cooperation]</ref>
===World's largest energy experiment at CERN===
The PAEC, partnered with country's leading [[Universities in Pakistan|universities]], send a large team of scientists and engineers to CERN to participate in [[Large Hadron Collider]] on 10 September 2008.<ref name="LahoreTech News, 2008">{{cite news|last1=et. al.|title=27 Pakistani Scientists working on CERN's LHC "Big Bang" Experiments|url=http://www.techlahore.com/2008/09/16/27-pakistani-scientists-working-on-cerns-lhc-big-bang-experiments/|accessdate=11 November 2014|agency=LahoreTech News|publisher=LahoreTech News, 2008|date=16 September 2008}}</ref> According to the news sources, the team of Pakistani scientists were keenly involved in the involved in the development of the [[Large Hadron Collider]]— the [[List of accelerators in particle physics#Hadron colliders|world's largest and highest-energy]] [[particle accelerator]].<ref name="LahoreTech News, 2008"/>
The data of the experiment was available for the Pakistani scientists who would examine the data and results would be accumulated afterwards by the Pakistan physicists.<ref name="Associate Press of Pakistan, 16 September 2008">{{cite news|last1=APP|title=27 Pakistani scientists took part in ‘Big Bang’ experiment|url=http://www.app.com.pk/en_/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=52897&Itemid=1|accessdate=11 November 2014|agency=Associate Press of Pakistan|publisher=Associate Press of Pakistan, 16 September 2008|date=16 September 2008}}</ref>
==PAEC Chairs==

==Corporate management==
The PAEC is chaired by the appointed chairperson by the [[Government of Pakistan|Government]] of Pakistan as the governmental notification is released.<ref name="Govt. of Pakistan, 1965">{{cite web|last1=PD|title=The Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission Ordinance, 1965|url=http://cmsdata.iucn.org/downloads/pakistan_atomic_energy_commission_ordinance_1965.pdf|publisher=Govt. of Pakistan, 1965|accessdate=11 November 2014|format=PDF|date=29 May 1965}}</ref> The PAEC's corporate management is organized by the [[Government of Pakistan|Government]] who awarded contracts to the potential candidates.<ref name="Govt. of Pakistan, 1965"/> Its full-time members are consisted of the appointed Chair; a finance member; and two technical members.<ref name="Govt. of Pakistan, 1965"/> Its part-time members are composed of the senior scientists and a chief scientific adviser to the government.<ref name="Govt. of Pakistan, 1965"/>
{{div col|colwidth=30em}} *Full Time [[Ex officio|Ex-officios]] ** Chairman— Chair (or [[Chief executive officer|CEO]]) of the PAEC.<ref name="Govt. of Pakistan, 1965"/> ** Finance Member— A [[Central Superior Services of Pakistan|civil servant]] from the [[Ministry of Finance (Pakistan)|Ministry of Finance]] (MoF).<ref name="Govt. of Pakistan, 1965"/> **Technical members— one from [[Pakistan Engineering Council|PEC]] and one from [[Pakistan Administrative Service]].<ref name="Govt. of Pakistan, 1965"/> *Part-Time [[Ex officio|Ex-officios]] **Senior scientist— A scientist in the services of the [[Ministry of Science and Technology (Pakistan)|Ministry of Science]] (MoST).<ref name="Govt. of Pakistan, 1965"/> **Senior Engineer—An engineer in the services of the [[Government of Pakistan|Government]] of Pakistan.<ref name="Govt. of Pakistan, 1965"/> **Science Adviser to the [[Government of Pakistan|Government]] of Pakistan.<ref name="Govt. of Pakistan, 1965"/>
{{div col end}}
The PAEC's corporate team are [[constitution]]ally bound to meet not less than four times every year for the execution of development projects involving [[nuclear power]] stations and the generation of [[electric power]].<ref name="Govt. of Pakistan, 1965"/> As of current, [[Muhammad Naeem (physicist)|Muhammad Naeem]] is the current chairman of the PAEC, appointed at the office since 2015.<ref name="Dawn News 2015">{{cite news|last1=DAWN|title=Mohammad Naeem appointed PAEC chairman|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1177846/mohammad-naeem-appointed-paec-chairman|date=24 April 2015}}</ref> The PAEC retains its autonomous corporate management and comes under the structure of the [[Nuclear Command Authority (Pakistan)|National Command Authority]].<ref name="National Command Authority ACT 2010">{{cite web|last1=PD|first1=Public Domain|title=National Command Authority ACT 2010|url=http://www.na.gov.pk/uploads/documents/1300934560_193.pdf|publisher=Gazette of Pakistan, PD|accessdate=11 November 2014|format=PDF}}</ref> The amendments carried out in 2010, the [[Nuclear Command Authority (Pakistan)|National Command Authority]] is now placed again under the [[Prime Minister of Pakistan]].<ref name="National Command Authority ACT 2010"/> The Chairman directly reports to the [[Prime Minister's Secretariat (Pakistan)|Prime Minister's Secretariat]] for its policy making and confirmation issues.<ref name="National Command Authority ACT 2010"/>

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Rex Tillerson |image = Rex Tillerson official portrait.jpg |office = 69th [[United States Secretary of State]] |president = [[Donald Trump]] |deputy = [[John J. Sullivan (diplomat)|John Sullivan]] |term_start = February 1, 2017 |term_end = March 31, 2018 |predecessor = [[John Kerry]] |successor = [[Mike Pompeo]] |birth_name = Rex Wayne Tillerson |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1952|3|23}} |birth_place = [[Wichita Falls, Texas]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = {{Unbulleted list |{{marriage|Jamie Lee Henry|1974}} |{{marriage|Renda St. Clair|June 21, 1986}} }} |children = 3 |education = {{nowrap|[[University of Texas at Austin]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]])}} |occupation = [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[ExxonMobil]] (2006–2016)
[[List of national presidents of the Boy Scouts of America|President]] of the [[Boy Scouts of America]] (2010–2012) |awards = [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]] (1965)
[[Order of Friendship]] (2013)
[[World Petroleum Council|Dewhurst Award]] (2017) }} {{Donald Trump series}} '''Rex Wayne Tillerson''' (born March 23, 1952) is a former [[American people|American]] government official and former energy executive who served as the [[List of Secretaries of State of the United States|69th]] [[United States Secretary of State]] from February 1, 2017, to March 31, 2018, under [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]].{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/tillerson-secretary-state-now-white-house/story?id=53712862|title=Tillerson still secretary of state for now: White House|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2018-03-13|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=2018-03-19}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/13/us/politics/trump-tillerson-pompeo.html|title=Trump Fires Rex Tillerson and Will Replace Him With C.I.A. Chief Pompeo|last=Baker|first=Peter|date=2018-03-13|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-19|last2=Harris|first2=Gardiner|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|last3=Landler|first3=Mark|quote=Mr. Tillerson said he planned to immediately step aside from his post, turning over all responsibilities by the end of the day to John J. Sullivan, the deputy secretary of state. During a short statement in a briefing room packed with reporters, Mr. Tillerson said he would end his service at midnight on March 31 ...}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-43391982|title=Sacked Tillerson issues Russia warning|date=2018-03-14|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en-GB|quote=Although Mr Tillerson will not officially leave until 31 March, his deputy John Sullivan will take over running the state department pending the confirmation of Mr Pompeo.}} Originally a civil engineer, Tillerson joined [[Exxon]] in 1975. He rose to become chairman and [[chief executive officer]] of [[ExxonMobil]], holding that position from 2006 until 2017, when he left to join the Trump administration. Tillerson began his career as a civil engineer and holds a bachelor's degree in civil engineering from the [[University of Texas at Austin]]. By 1989 he had become general manager of the Exxon USA central production division. In 1995 he became president of Exxon Yemen Inc. and Esso Exploration and Production Khorat Inc. In 2006 Tillerson was elected chair and chief executive of Exxon, the world's sixth [[largest company by revenue]].{{cite web|url=http://corporate.exxonmobil.com/en/company/about-us/management/rex-w-tillerson?parentId=663fb338-1f34-4a5a-ac09-26e2cfc2d5ad |title=Archive of ExxonMobil Biography of Rex W. Tillerson, Chairman and CEO |publisher=ExxonMobil Corporation |accessdate=January 25, 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160823215602/http://corporate.exxonmobil.com/en/company/about-us/management/rex-w-tillerson?parentId=663fb338-1f34-4a5a-ac09-26e2cfc2d5ad |archivedate=August 23, 2016 |df= }}{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/steveschaefer/2016/05/25/the-worlds-largest-companies-2016/ |title=The World's Largest Companies 2016|first1=Steve |last1=Schaefer |work=Forbes |date=May 25, 2016|accessdate=December 13, 2016}} Tillerson retired from Exxon effective January 1, 2017.{{cite web |url=http://news.exxonmobil.com/press-release/rex-tillerson-retire-darren-woods-elected-chairman-ceo-exxon-mobil-corporation |title=Rex Tillerson to Retire, Darren Woods Elected Chairman, CEO of ExxonMobil Corporation |publisher=ExxonMobil Corporation |date=December 14, 2016 |accessdate=December 15, 2016}} He is a member of the [[National Academy of Engineering]]. Tillerson is a long-time volunteer with the [[Boy Scouts of America]] and earned the rank of [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]]. From 2010 to 2012 he was the [[List of national presidents of the Boy Scouts of America|national president of the Boy Scouts]], its highest non-executive position. He is a long-time contributor to [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] campaigns, but did not donate to [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump's presidential campaign]]. In 2014, Tillerson, who had made business deals on behalf of Exxon with [[President of Russia|President]] [[Vladimir Putin]] of [[Russia]], opposed the [[International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis|sanctions against Russia]].{{cite news|last1=Plumer|first1=Brad|title=Rex Tillerson's potentially huge conflict of interest over Russia and oil, explained|url=https://www.vox.com/energy-and-environment/2016/12/14/13940866/trump-rex-tillerson-sanctions-russia|accessdate=January 25, 2017|publisher=Vox|date=December 14, 2016}} He has previously been the director of the joint United States-Russia oil company [[Exxon Neftegas]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/dec/18/leak-rex-tillerson-director-bahamas-based-us-russian-oil-company|title=Leak reveals Rex Tillerson was director of Bahamas-based US-Russian oil firm|first1=Luke|last1=Harding|first2=Hannes|last2=Munzinger|date=December 18, 2016|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}} Tillerson joined the Trump administration on February 1, 2017. Trump dismissed Tillerson on March 13, 2018, making his tenure one of the shortest in recent history. Trump stated that he would nominate [[Director of the Central Intelligence Agency|CIA Director]] [[Mike Pompeo]] to replace Tillerson.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-43388723|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=March 13, 2018|title=Trump sacks Rex Tillerson as state secretary}} Tillerson's term officially ended on March 31, 2018; Deputy Secretary of State [[John J. Sullivan (diplomat)|John Sullivan]] served as acting secretary until Pompeo was sworn in.{{cite web|accessdate=2018-03-13 |work=The Hill|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/378175-tillerson-doesnt-thank-trump-in-farewell-speech |title=Tillerson doesn't thank Trump in post-firing speech |first=Brett |last=Samuels |date=March 13, 2018}} Tillerson's tenure was characterized by a lack of visibility in comparison to his predecessors in the traditionally high-profile position of Secretary of State.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/11/us/politics/rex-tillerson-trump-white-house.html|title=Tillerson Leads From State Dept. Shadows as White House Steps In|last=Sanger|first=David E.|date=March 11, 2017|work=The New York Times}}{{Cite news|author=Nahal Toosi|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/03/state-department-rex-tillerson-235689|title=State Dept. staffers have one question: Where’s Rex?|work=Politico|date=October 18, 2017}}{{cite web|author=Robbie Gramer & Dan de Luce|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/09/05/wheres-rex-tillerson-state-department-missing-in-action-north-korea-diplomacy-asia/|title=Where’s Rex?|website=Foreign Policy|date=September 5, 2017}} According to the [[American Foreign Service Association]], during Tillerson's tenure, new applications to work for the [[U.S. Foreign Service|Foreign Service]] fell by 50%, and 60% of high-ranking career diplomats in the State Department resigned.Zack Beauchamp, [https://www.vox.com/world/2018/3/13/16029526/rex-tillerson-fired-state-department Rex Tillerson has been fired. Experts say he did damage that could last "a generation"], ''Vox'' (March 13, 2018). == Early life == Tillerson was born on March 23, 1952, in [[Wichita Falls, Texas]], the son of Patty Sue (née Patton) and Bobby Joe Tillerson,{{cite web |url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:V6S5-GLP|title=Texas Birth Index, 1903–1997|work=FamilySearch Database|date=December 5, 2014|accessdate=December 15, 2016}} and named after [[Rex Allen]] and [[John Wayne]], two Hollywood actors famous for playing cowboys.{{cite news|last1=Filkins|first1=Dexter|authorlink=Dexter Filkins|title=Rex Tillerson at the Breaking Point|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/10/16/rex-tillerson-at-the-breaking-point|accessdate=November 23, 2017|work=[[The New Yorker]]|issue=October 16, 2017}} He was raised in [[Vernon, Texas]]; [[Stillwater, Oklahoma]]; and [[Huntsville, Texas]].{{cite news|first=Nahal |last=Toosi|title=Who is Rex Tillerson?|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/who-is-rex-tillerson-233362|accessdate=April 1, 2017|work=[[Politico]] |date=January 11, 2017}}{{cite book|title=The Alcalde|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0-MDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA47|accessdate=April 2, 2017|date=November 2007|publisher=Emmis Communications|page=47}} He has two sisters,{{cite news|first=Debbie |last=Lord|title=Read Rex Tillerson's opening statement during the Senate confirmation hearing|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/national/read-rex-tillerson-opening-statement-during-the-senate-confirmation-hearing/brvmU4tnpdHSjTHEmxvAWP/|accessdate=April 1, 2017|work=Palm Beach Post|date=January 11, 2017}} Rae Ann Hamilton, a physician who resides in [[Abilene, Texas]],{{cite news|title=Tillerson's sister says he would do 'an incredible job' |url=http://www.reporternews.com/story/news/local/texas/2016/12/13/tillersons-sister-says-he-would-do-incredible-job/95396250/|first=Brian |last=Bethel |accessdate=April 1, 2017|work=Abilene Reporter News|date=December 13, 2016}} and Jo Lynn Peters, a high school educator. Tillerson's father was an executive of the [[Boy Scouts of America]] organization, and this led to his family's move to Huntsville, Texas. Tillerson himself has been active in the Boy Scouts for most of his life, and in his youth he earned the rank of [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]].{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/09/04/mazzuca-ceos-leaders-lead-citizen-cx_mk_0904scouts.html|title=Teaching Leadership: Scouts Honor|accessdate=September 5, 2007|date=September 4, 2007|work=[[Forbes]]|first=Matthew|last=Kirdahy}}{{cite news|accessdate=February 12, 2017|url=https://blog.scoutingmagazine.org/2016/12/13/distinguished-eagle-scout-rex-tillerson-nominated-as-secretary-of-state/ |work=Scouting Magazine |title=Eagle Scout Rex Tillerson named secretary of state |first=Bryan |last=Wendell |date=December 13, 2016}} At age 14, he began to work as a [[bus boy]] in the [[student union building]] at [[Oklahoma State University]].{{cite news|first=Glenn |last=Hunter|title=Why Rex Tillerson, Down-to-Earth Texan, Might Make a Good Secretary of State|url=https://www.dmagazine.com/business-economy/2016/12/why-rex-tillerson-down-to-earth-texan-might-make-a-good-secretary-of-state/|accessdate=April 1, 2017|work=D Magazine|date=December 11, 2016}} Two years later in 1968 he became a [[janitor]] working in one of the engineering buildings at the university. On weekends, he worked picking cotton. Tillerson graduated from [[Huntsville High School (Texas)|Huntsville High School]]{{cite news|first=Cody |last=Stark|title=Huntsville High School graduate Rex Tillerson: 'An All-American kid'|url=http://www.itemonline.com/news/local_news/huntsville-high-school-graduate-rex-tillerson-an-all-american-kid/article_24eb750c-973b-59d8-a70c-e5c23d9c7fc3.html|accessdate=April 2, 2017|work=The Huntsville|date=December 23, 2016}} in 1970. He was a section leader for the [[Percussion instrument|percussion]] section of his [[high school band]], in which he played the [[kettle drums]] and [[snare drum]], and he earned spots in the all-district and all-region bands during his senior year. Tillerson received a college scholarship from [[the University of Texas Longhorn Band]]. He received a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[Civil Engineering]] from the [[University of Texas at Austin]] in 1975.{{cite web|url=http://www.engr.utexas.edu/alumni/distinguished-alumni/deg/2006|title=2006 Distinguished Engineering Graduate: Rex W. Tillerson, B.S.C.E. 1975, Chairman and CEO, ExxonMobil Corporation|work=Cockrell School of Engineering, University of Texas}} During his time at UT Austin, he was involved with the [[Tejas Club]],{{cite web|last=Barnhill|first=Ted|title=Distinguishing Features: The Distinguished Alumni of 2007|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0-MDAAAAMBAJ|work=The Alcalde|publisher=Texas Exes|accessdate=January 22, 2012}} and the [[marching band]]. == Business career == === Exxon === [[File:Vice President Cheney Talks with Rex Tillerson of Exxon Mobil Corporation in His West Wing Office.jpg|thumb|[[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Dick Cheney]] and Tillerson, 2007]] Tillerson joined [[Exxon Company]] USA in 1975 as a production engineer. In 1989, Tillerson became general manager of the central production division of Exxon USA. In 1995, he became President of Exxon Yemen Inc. and Esso Exploration and Production Khorat Inc. In 1998, he became a vice president of Exxon Ventures (CIS) and president of [[Exxon Neftegas]] Limited with responsibility for Exxon's holdings in Russia and the [[Caspian Sea]]. He then entered Exxon into the [[Sakhalin-I]] consortium with [[Rosneft]].{{cite news|last1=Rogin|first1=Josh|title=Inside Rex Tillerson’s long romance with Russia|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/josh-rogin/wp/2016/12/13/inside-rex-tillersons-long-romance-with-russia/|accessdate=November 26, 2017|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=December 13, 2016}} In 1999, with the merger of Exxon and Mobil, he was named executive vice president of ExxonMobil Development Company. In 2004, he became president and director of ExxonMobil.{{cite news|first=Steve |last=Coll |title=Rex Tillerson, from a Corporate Oil Sovereign to the State Department |url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/rex-tillerson-from-a-corporate-oil-sovereign-to-the-state-department|accessdate=April 1, 2017|work=The New Yorker|date=December 11, 2016}} Upon this appointment Tillerson's replacement of [[Lee Raymond]] as [[CEO]] of Exxon Mobil was implied.{{cite news|first1=David |last1=Koenig|title=Exxon Mobil Names Heir Apparent for CEO|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A13105-2004Feb27.html|accessdate=April 2, 2017|work=Washington Post|date=February 27, 2004}} His major competitor was Ed Galante, another Exxon executive.{{cite news|first1=Carola |last1=Hoyos|first2=Dan |last2=Roberts|title=Seamless transition to the top for the new 'Mr Exxon'|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/4f9832f0-05d7-11da-883e-00000e2511c8.html?ft_site=falcon&desktop=true#axzz4d4yuPiYo|accessdate=April 2, 2017|work=Financial Times|date=August 5, 2005}} On January 1, 2006, Tillerson was elected chairman and chief executive officer (CEO), following the retirement of Lee Raymond. At the time, Exxon had 80,000 employees, did business in nearly 200 countries, and had an annual revenue of nearly $400 billion. Under Tillerson's leadership, ExxonMobil cooperated closely with [[Saudi Arabia]], the world's largest [[List of countries by oil exports|oil exporter]] and a longtime U.S. ally; [[Qatar]] and the [[United Arab Emirates]]."{{cite web |accessdate= |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/en/originals/2016/12/rex-tillerson-secretary-state-middle-east-trump.html |title=What Exxon's Rex Tillerson might mean as secretary of state |work=Al-Monitor |first=Laura |last=Rozen |date=December 13, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202054431/http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/en/originals/2016/12/rex-tillerson-secretary-state-middle-east-trump.html |archive-date=February 2, 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} From 2003 to 2005, a European subsidiary of ExxonMobil, [[Infineum]], operated in the Middle East providing sales to [[Iran]], [[Sudan]] and [[Syria]]. ExxonMobil stated that they followed all legal framework and that such sales were minuscule compared to their annual revenue of $371 billion at the time.{{cite news|last1=Dorell|first1=Oren|title=ExxonMobil and Iran did business under secretary of State nominee Tillerson|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/01/09/exxonmobil-and-iran-did-business-under-secretary-state-nominee-tillerson/96359776/|work=[[USA TODAY]]|date=January 9, 2017}} In 2009, ExxonMobil acquired [[XTO Energy]], a major natural gas producer, for $31 billion in stock. Michael Corkery of the ''Wall Street Journal'' wrote that "Tillerson's legacy rides on the XTO Deal."{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/deals/2009/12/14/rexs-legacy-rides-on-xto-deal/tab/article/|title=King Rex Tillerson's Legacy Rides on the XTO Deal|accessdate=January 26, 2010|date=December 14, 2009|work=The Wall Street Journal|first=Michael|last=Corkery}} Tillerson approved Exxon negotiating a multibillion-dollar deal with the government of [[Iraqi Kurdistan]], despite opposition from President [[Barack Obama]] and Iraqi [[Prime Minister of Iraq|Prime Minister]] [[Nouri al-Maliki]], both of whom argued it would increase regional instability. Tillerson lobbied against Rule 1504 of the [[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act|Dodd–Frank reform and protections]], which would have required Exxon to disclose payments to foreign governments. In 2017, Congress voted to overturn Rule 1504 one hour before Tillerson was confirmed as Secretary of State. On January 4, 2017, ''[[The Financial Times]]'' reported that Tillerson would cut his ExxonMobil ties if he became Secretary of State.{{cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/98038198-d23f-11e6-9341-7393bb2e1b51|title=Tillerson set for $180m payout if confirmed as secretary of state|work=The Financial Times|date=January 4, 2017|first=Ed|last=Crooks|accessdate=February 2, 2017}} [[Walter Shaub]], the director of the [[United States Office of Government Ethics]], said he was proud of the ethics agreement developed for Tillerson, who was now "free of financial conflicts of interest. His ethics agreement serves as a sterling model for what we'd like to see with other nominees."{{cite web|url=https://assets.documentcloud.org/documents/3280298/Remarks-of-Office-of-Government-Ethics-Director.pdf|title=Remarks of the Office of Government Ethics Director|via=DocumentCloud}}{{cite web|accessdate=February 3, 2017 |url=https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/20170111_oge_shaub_remarks.pdf|title=Remarks of Walter M. Shaub, Jr., Director, U.S. Office of Government Ethics, as prepared for delivery at 4:00 p.m. on January 11, 2017, at the Brookings Institution|work=The Brookings Institution|date=January 11, 2017}} ==== Ties with Russia ==== [[File:Igor Sechin, Vladimir Putin, Rex Tillerson (2012-06-15) 02.jpg|thumb|Tillerson with President [[Vladimir Putin]] and [[Igor Sechin]], the head of state-controlled energy giant [[Rosneft]], in [[Tuapse]], 2012]] Tillerson has ties with [[President of Russia|President]] [[Vladimir Putin]] of [[Russia]].{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/deals-with-vladimir-putin-helped-fuel-rise-of-secretary-of-state-nominee-rex-tillerson-1481626925 |title=Global Deals That Made Exxon's CEO Now Pose Big Test |first1=Justin |last1=Scheck |first2=James |last2=Marson |first3=Russell |last3=Gold |work=The Wall Street Journal|date=December 13, 2015|accessdate=December 13, 2016}} They have been associates since Tillerson represented Exxon's interests in Russia, the world's [[List of countries by oil production|largest producer]] of crude oil, during Russian President [[Boris Yeltsin]]'s tenure.{{cite news|first=Bradley |last=Olson |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/donald-trump-candidate-for-state-has-close-ties-to-vladimir-putin-1481033938 |title=Rex Tillerson, a Candidate for Secretary of State, Has Ties to Vladimir Putin |work=The Wall Street Journal|date=December 6, 2016}} Tillerson was responsible for the development of a partnership between Exxon and state-owned oil company Rosneft and the ultimately unsuccessful attempt to acquire a stake in [[Yukos]], owned by [[Mikhail Khodorkovsky]], before the firm was nationalized after Khodorkovsky's arrest.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2017/01/tillerson-confirmation-senate-mccain-graham-exxonmobil-russia-putin/512750/|title=A Brief Guide to Rex Tillerson's Controversial Foreign Ties|last=Mahanta|first=Siddhartha|work=The Atlantic|access-date=July 2, 2017|language=en-US}} [[John Hamre]], the President and CEO of the [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]], of which Tillerson is a board member, states that Tillerson "has had more interactive time with Vladimir Putin than probably any other American, with the exception of Dr. [[Henry Kissinger]]." Tillerson was a friend of [[Igor Sechin]],{{cite news|last1=Ioffe|first1=Julia|title=What It Really Means to Be a 'Friend of Putin'|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/12/rex-tillerson-exxon-putin-russia-ties-friend-214515|accessdate=December 11, 2016|work=Politico Magazine|date=December 10, 2016}} the Executive Chairman of [[Rosneft]], the Russian state oil company, and leader of the Kremlin's ''[[Siloviki]]'' (security/military) faction,{{cite web|last1=Hahn|first1=Gordon|authorlink1=Gordon M. Hahn|title=The Siloviki Downgraded. In Russia's New Configuration of Power |url=http://www.russiaotherpointsofview.com/2008/07/the-siloviki-do.html |accessdate=December 11, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101231105525/http://www.russiaotherpointsofview.com/2008/07/the-siloviki-do.html |archivedate=December 31, 2010 |date=July 21, 2008}} who has been described as "Russia's second-most powerful person" after Putin.{{cite news|last1=Peleschuk|first1=Dan|title=Think it's just Putin who runs Russia? Guess again|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/102294358|accessdate=December 11, 2016|publisher=CNBC|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225012706/http://www.cnbc.com/id/102294358|archivedate=December 25, 2014}} Exxon owns a [[dacha]] next door to Sechin's and Tillerson would often visit him there. Tillerson led Sechin on a tour of New York City, dining on [[caviar]] with him and Putin at the [[Per Se (restaurant)|''Per Se'' restaurant]]. In 2006, Exxon avoided making any government concessions in its [[Sakhalin-I]] oil field after [[Royal Dutch Shell]] was forced to sell half of its ownership in [[Sakhalin-II]] by the Russian government. In August 2011, Putin attended a ceremony in [[Sochi]] where Tillerson and Sechin signed an agreement between ExxonMobil and [[Rosneft]] to drill the [[East-Prinovozemelsky field]] in the [[Arctic Ocean]] valued at up to $300 billion.{{cite news |last1=Parfitt|first1=Tom|last2=Rushe|first2=Dominic|title=ExxonMobil clinches Arctic oil deal with Rosneft |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/aug/30/exxon-rosneft-oil-arctic|accessdate=November 26, 2017 |work=[[The Guardian]]|date=August 30, 2011}}{{cite news |last=Trefgarne|first=George|title=Vladimir Putin plays for high stakes in the oil game |work=The Daily Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/energy/oil/8733104/Vladimir-Putin-plays-for-high-stakes-in-the-oil-game.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024195933/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/energy/oil/8733104/Vladimir-Putin-plays-for-high-stakes-in-the-oil-game.html |archive-date=October 24, 2014|date=August 31, 2011|accessdate=December 10, 2016}} The Rosneft deal also gave the state-owned oil company a 30% stake in Exxon owned assets in the U.S. [[Gulf of Mexico]], Canada, and West Texas. The company began drilling in the [[Kara Sea]] in the summer of 2014, and a round of [[International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis|sanctions against Russia]] introduced in September that year due to the [[Ukrainian crisis]] was to have brought the project to a halt in mid-September.{{cite news|last1=Reed|first1=Stanley |first2=Clifford |last2=Krauss|date=September 12, 2014 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/13/business/energy-environment/new-sanctions-to-stall-exxons-arctic-oil-plans.html |title=New Sanctions to Stall Exxon's Arctic Oil Plans |work=The New York Times |accessdate=December 10, 2016}}{{cite news|last=Williams |first=Cara |date=September 19, 2014 |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/europe/la-fg-russia-sanctions-exxonmobil-20140919-story.html |title=ExxonMobil said to halt drilling in $700-million project in Russia |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=December 10, 2016}} Nevertheless, the company was granted a reprieve that stretched the window to work until October 10, which enabled it to discover a major field with about 750 million barrels of new oil for Russia.{{cite news|title=Rex Tillerson's Company, Exxon, Has Billions at Stake Over Sanctions on Russia|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/12/world/europe/rex-tillersons-company-exxon-has-billions-at-stake-over-russia-sanctions.html|date=December 12, 2016|accessdate=December 12, 2016|first1=Andrew E. |last1=Kramer |first2=Clifford |last2=Krauss}} In July 2017, the [[United States Department of the Treasury|U.S. Treasury]]'s [[Office of Foreign Assets Control]] fined ExxonMobil $2 million for violating sanctions in its dealings with Sechin, leading the company to sue the government.{{cite news |last1=Paletta|first1=Damian|last2=Morello|first2=Carol|title=The strange legal battle that is pitting Trump’s secretaries of the Treasury and State against each other |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2017/07/20/u-s-says-exxonmobil-violated-russia-sanctions-while-tillerson-was-ceo/|accessdate=July 21, 2017|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=July 21, 2017|page=A1}}{{cite press release|title=The U.S. Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control Assesses a Civil Monetary Penalty Against ExxonMobil Corporation|url=https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/OFAC-Enforcement/Pages/20170720.aspx|accessdate=July 21, 2017|work=www.treasury.gov|date=July 20, 2017|language=en-us}} In 2013, Tillerson was awarded the [[Order of Friendship]] by Putin for his contribution to developing cooperation in the energy sector.{{cite web |url=http://en.kremlin.ru/events/president/news/18382|title=Meeting with energy company heads|date=June 21, 2013|work=Kremlin}}{{cite news|title=Rex Tillerson - the wild card diplomat|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38281954|accessdate=March 29, 2017|work=BBC News |date=February 1, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2017/mar/02/donald-trump-russia-campaign-moscow|title=Trump associates' links with Russia: what we know so far |first1=Paul |last1=Torpey |first2=Cath |last2=Levett |first3=Paul|last3=Torpey |first4=Cath|last4=Levett |accessdate=November 1, 2017|website=Theguardian.com}} In June 2017, Tillerson said Trump had asked him to "stabilize the relationship (with Russia) and build trust."{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4806809/rex-tillerson-donald-trump-russia/|title=Tillerson Says Trump Asked Him to Re-Engage Russia|first=Nick|last=Perry|website=Time|access-date=July 2, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170628063435/http://time.com/4806809/rex-tillerson-donald-trump-russia/|archive-date=June 28, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ==== Compensation ==== In 2012, Tillerson's compensation package was $40.5 million.{{cite news|first=Robert |last=Creamer|title=The Blog: Jamie Dimon's Big Pay Raise – and the Minimum Wage|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/robert-creamer/jamie-dimons-big-pay-rais_b_4722678.html|work=The Huffington Post|date=February 4, 2014|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} It was $28.1 million in 2013, $33.1 million in 2014, and $27.2 million in 2015.{{cite news|title=Profits are down at ExxonMobil, but don't cry for CEO Rex Tillerson|first=Steve|last=Mufson|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/profits-are-down-at-exxonmobil-but-dont-cry-for-ceo-rex-tillerson/2016/04/29/d6401e0c-0d60-11e6-a6b6-2e6de3695b0e_story.html|work=The Washington Post|date=April 29, 2016|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} In late 2016, Tillerson held $54 million of Exxon stock, and had a right to deferred stock worth approximately $180 million over the next 10 years.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/dec/18/donald-trump-senate-backlash-cabinet-of-billionaires|title=Donald Trump faces Senate backlash over 'cabinet of billionaires'|first=Rupert|last=Neate|date=December 17, 2016|newspaper=The Guardian}} Tillerson is estimated to be worth at least $300 million. When he left Exxon, Tillerson was four months away from retirement, at which time he would have been entitled to a $180 million retirement package. He owns two ranches in Texas, where his wife, Renda, raises [[cutting horses]]. On January 3, 2017, ExxonMobil announced they had reached an agreement with Tillerson "to sever all ties with the company to comply with conflict-of-interest requirements associated with his nomination as secretary of state."{{cite press release|url=http://news.exxonmobil.com/press-release/exxonmobil-tillerson-reach-agreement-comply-conflict-interest-requirements|date= January 3, 2017|title=ExxonMobil, Tillerson Reach Agreement to Comply with Conflict of Interest Requirements|publisher=Exxon Mobil}} ==== Wayne Tracker alias ==== While CEO of ExxonMobil, Tillerson used an alias email address "Wayne Tracker" for eight years and sent thousands of messages.{{cite news|last1=Scheyder|first1=Ernest|title=Tillerson's email alias was prompted by business needs, Exxon says|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-tillerson-email-idUSKBN16L2QD|accessdate=March 20, 2017|publisher=Reuters|date=March 14, 2017}} In response to a [[subpoena]] issued by the [[New York State Attorney General]]'s Office (part of a state investigation into [[ExxonMobil climate change controversy|whether Exxon had misled investors and the public about climate change]]), Exxon produced about 60 emails associated with the "Wayne Tracker" account, but did not inform investigators that they were Tillerson's.[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-39274174 Rex Tillerson 'used email alias' at Exxon to talk climate change], BBC News (March 15, 2017). ExxonMobil stated that the account was "used for everyday business" needs such as "secure and expedited communications" between Tillerson and top company executives. Tillerson's use of the alias became publicly known in March 2017, after [[New York State Attorney General]] [[Eric Schneiderman]] wrote in a letter to a judge that Tillerson had used the "Wayne Tracker" email for at least seven years. Later that month, Exxon revealed that emails from the alias account from September 2014 to September 2015 were missing; a further search recovered some emails, but none between September 5, 2014, and November 28, 2014. An attorney for Exxon said that a "unique issue" limited to that account led to emails being automatically deleted.{{cite web|title=In the Matter of the Application of the People of the State of New York, by Eric T. Schneiderman, Index No. 451962/2016|url=https://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/nyscef/ViewDocument?docIndex=4DzZGoEJQiW/RZR4m4RXbQ==|publisher=New York State Unified Court System|accessdate=March 23, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Berke|first1=Jeremy|title=Exxon admits it lost up to a year's worth of Rex Tillerson's 'Wayne Tracker' emails|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/rex-tillerson-exxon-email-climate-change-schneiderman-2017-3|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate= March 23, 2017}} === Other affiliations === Tillerson is a trustee of the [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]] and the [[American Petroleum Institute]].{{cite web|url=https://www.csis.org/people/rex-w-tillerson|title=Rex W. Tillerson – Center for Strategic and International Studies|publisher=csis.org|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} He is also a member of the [[Business Roundtable]]. In 2013, he became a member of the [[National Academy of Engineering]]. He was a member of the executive committee of [[The Business Council]] for 2011 and 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.thebusinesscouncil.org/about/excommittee.aspx |title=The Business Council: Executive Committee 2011–2012 |work=The Business Council |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120722222304/http://www.thebusinesscouncil.org/about/excommittee.aspx |archivedate=July 22, 2012 |df= }} Tillerson is a long-time volunteer with the [[Boy Scouts of America]] (BSA), and from 2010 to 2012 was [[List of national presidents of the Boy Scouts of America|their national president]], its highest non-executive position.{{cite web|title=CEO of Exxon Mobil Named National Boy Scouts of America President|url=http://www.scoutingnews.org/rex-tillerson/|publisher=scoutingnews.org|accessdate=December 13, 2016}}{{cite news|last=James|first=Osbourne|title=Exxon Mobil CEO Rex Tillerson an Eagle Scout to the core|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/business/business/2014/09/06/exxon-mobil-ceo-rex-tillerson-an-eagle-scout-to-the-core|work=Dallas News|date=September 1, 2014}} Tillerson is a [[Distinguished Eagle Scout]], and his father was a BSA executive. Tillerson is a long-time supporter of the BSA and has said, "I think the highlight of my youth and adolescent years were my achievements in Scouting." In 2009, Tillerson was inducted into the Eagle Scout Hall of Fame of the [[Greater New York Councils]].{{cite press release |author=Boy Scouts of America |title=Boy Scouts Inducts Rex Tillerson, Chairman and CEO of ExxonMobil, Into Eagle Scout Hall of Fame |url=http://www.scoutingnewsroom.org/press-releases/boy-scouts-inducts-rex-tillerson-chairman-and-ceo-of-exxonmobil-into-eagle-scout-hall-of-fame/ |work=Boy Scouts of America |date=October 28, 2009 |access-date=December 13, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161216154116/http://www.scoutingnewsroom.org/press-releases/boy-scouts-inducts-rex-tillerson-chairman-and-ceo-of-exxonmobil-into-eagle-scout-hall-of-fame/ |archive-date=December 16, 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} Ray L. Hunt, a close friend and the Chairman of Hunt Consolidated, told the Dallas Morning News, "To understand Rex Tillerson, you need to understand Scouting." After the end of his term as BSA president, he remained on the organization's [[National Executive Board of the Boy Scouts of America|National Executive Board]]. There he played a significant role in the board's 2013 [[Boy Scouts of America membership controversies#Position on homosexuality|decision to rescind]] the long-standing ban on openly gay youth as members. According to Center for Strategic and International Studies president [[John Hamre]], Tillerson was instrumental in the change and "a key leader in helping the group come to a consensus".{{cite news|last1=Krauss|first1=Clifford|title=Rex Tillerson, an Aggressive Dealmaker Whose Ties With Russia May Prompt Scrutiny|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/11/business/rex-tillerson-secretary-of-state-russia.html|work=The New York Times|date=December 11, 2016}} On July 9, 2017, Tillerson received the Dewhurst Award from the [[World Petroleum Council]] in recognition for "outstanding contribution to the oil and gas industry" during his 41 years at Exxon Mobil.{{cite web|title=Rex Tillerson to receive WPC Dewhurst Award|url=http://www.world-petroleum.org/resources/press-releases/367-rex-tillerson-to-receive-wpc-dewhurst-award|website=World Petroleum Council|accessdate=July 10, 2017}} == Secretary of State (2017–2018) == === Nomination and confirmation === [[File:Rex Tillerson confirmation hearing.jpg|right|thumb|Tillerson at his confirmation hearing on January 11, 2017]] [[File:Tillerson sworn in.jpg|thumb|Tillerson being sworn in as Secretary of State on February 1, 2017]] [[File:Secretary Tillerson Delivers Welcome Remarks to State Department Employees on his First Day (31827201164).jpg|right|thumb|Tillerson delivering welcome remarks at the State Department on his first official day as Secretary of State]] Tillerson was first recommended to then-[[President-elect of the United States|President-elect]] [[Donald Trump|Trump]] for the [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] role by former Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]], during her meeting with Trump in late November 2016. Rice's recommendation of Tillerson to Trump was backed up by former [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert Gates]], three days later.[http://www.politico.com/blogs/donald-trump-administration/2016/12/rex-tillerson-exxonmobil-secretary-state-232455 "ExxonMobil CEO Tillerson emerging as frontrunner for secretary of state"]. Henry C. Jackson, Josh Dawsey and Eliana Johnson, [[Politico]]. December 9, 2016. Media speculation that he was being considered for the position began on December 5, 2016.{{cite news|title=Exxon CEO Now a Contender for Donald Trump's Secretary of State|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/exxon-ceo-now-a-contender-for-donald-trumps-secretary-of-state-1480878402|date=December 5, 2016|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal}} On December 9, transition officials reported that Tillerson was the top candidate for the position, surpassing contenders such as [[Mitt Romney]] and [[David Petraeus]].{{cite news|title=Exxon's Rex Tillerson Is Top Candidate for Secretary of State|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/exxons-rex-tillerson-is-top-candidate-for-secretary-of-state-1481318464|date=December 9, 2016 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal}} His nomination was reportedly advocated by [[Steve Bannon]] and [[Jared Kushner]].Sanger, David E., Maggie Haberman & Clifford Krauss, [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/10/us/politics/rex-tillerson-secretary-of-state-trump.html "Rex Tillerson, Exxon Chief, Is Expected to Be Pick for Secretary of State"], ''The New York Times'', December 10, 2016. On January 20, 2017, shortly after being [[Inauguration of Donald Trump|sworn in]] as [[President of the United States]], Trump formally sent his nomination of Tillerson as Secretary of State to the [[United States Senate]].{{cite web|title=Nominations Sent to the Senate|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/01/20/nominations-sent-senate|work=White House|date=January 20, 2017|accessdate=February 22, 2017}} The [[Senate Foreign Relations Committee]] approved Tillerson's nomination 11–10, a strict party line vote, on January 23, 2017.{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/23/politics/senate-committee-approves-tillerson-for-secretary-of-state/index.html|title=Senate committee approves Tillerson for secretary of state|first=Nicole|last=Gaouette|work=CNN}} The Senate [[Formation of Donald Trump's Cabinet#Senate votes|confirmed]] Tillerson as Secretary of State on February 1, 2017. The Senate voted 56 to 43, with all 52 Republicans in support of his nomination as well as three Democrats and one independent.{{cite web|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=115&session=1&vote=00036|title=PN25 Roll call confirmation vote|last=|first=|date=February 1, 2017|website=United States Senate|access-date=February 1, 2017}} He was sworn in on the same day by [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Mike Pence]].{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/02/01/remarks-president-trump-and-vice-president-pence-swearing-ceremony|title=Remarks by President Trump and Vice President Pence at Swearing-In Ceremony for Secretary of State Rex Tillerson|date=February 1, 2017|publisher=}} The number of votes against Tillerson's confirmation was unusual for a Secretary of State. The previous record for votes against a nominee for Secretary of State had been fourteen.{{cite web|title=Rex Tillerson Is Confirmed as Secretary of State Amid Record Opposition|date=February 1, 2018|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/01/us/politics/rex-tillerson-secretary-of-state-confirmed.html|work=New York Times|last=Harris|first=Gardiner |accessdate=March 18, 2018}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! colspan="3" |Confirmation process |- !Voting body !Vote date !Vote results |- | Senate Committee on Foreign Relations | January 23, 2017 | style="background:lightblue;" |11–10 |- | Full Senate | February 1, 2017 |style="background:lightgreen;" |56–43 |} === Tenure === On February 15, 2017, Tillerson embarked on his first overseas trip as Secretary of State to [[Bonn, Germany]], meeting with foreign ministers from the [[G20]].{{cite web|last=Morello|first=Carol|title=Tillerson in Germany on his first trip abroad as U.S. secretary of state |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/tillerson-in-germany-on-his-first-overseas-trip/2017/02/15/61f728ba-f2fc-11e6-9fb1-2d8f3fc9c0ed_story.html|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=February 15, 2017|access-date=February 25, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Tillerson and Mattis in guarded approach to Russia|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38988639|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=February 16, 2017|access-date=February 25, 2017}} In Bonn, Tillerson had meetings with [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Foreign Minister]] [[Sergey Lavrov]] of [[Russia]] and [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[Boris Johnson]] of the [[United Kingdom]],{{cite web|title=Rex Tillerson Meets Russian Counterpart in First Trip as Top U.S. Diplomat|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/16/world/europe/rex-tillerson-russia.html|work=[[New York Times]] |date=February 16, 2017|access-date=February 25, 2017|last=Harris|first=Cardiner}} as well as his counterparts from Italy, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Oman, and the United Arab Emirates.{{cite web|title=Tillerson arrives in Bonn amid questions over U.S. foreign policy|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-g20-tillerson-idUSKBN15U24J|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=February 15, 2017|access-date=February 25, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Meeting on Yemen |url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2017/02/267661.htm|publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]]|date=February 16, 2017|access-date=February 25, 2017}} Tillerson urged Russia to withdraw from eastern Ukraine, stating that "the United States will consider working with Russia when we can find areas of practical cooperation that will benefit the American people. Where we do not see eye to eye, the United States will stand up for the interests and values of America and her allies. As we search for new common ground, we expect Russia to honor its commitment to the [[Minsk agreements]] and work to de-escalate the violence in Ukraine." Tillerson also reaffirmed U.S. commitment to defending South Korea and Japan.{{cite web|last=Morello|first=Carol|title=Tillerson, in diplomatic debut, urges Russia to pull back in eastern Ukraine|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/tillerson-and-lavrov-meet-for-first-time-in-bonn/2017/02/16/256d571a-f2fd-11e6-9fb1-2d8f3fc9c0ed_story.html|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=February 16, 2017|access-date=February 25, 2017}} [[File:Secretary Tillerson Meets with Turkish President Erdogan in Ankara (32921677663).jpg|thumb|left|Tillerson with Turkish President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan|Erdoğan]] at the [[Presidential Complex]] in [[Ankara]], March 30, 2017]] Tillerson made his first visit to Mexico on February 23, 2017, traveling with [[Secretary of Homeland Security]] [[John F. Kelly]]. When meeting with [[Secretary of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)|Secretary of Foreign Affairs]] [[Luis Videgaray Caso]] of [[Mexico]], Tillerson acknowledged differences between the U.S. and Mexico on views of [[Mexico–United States border#Security|border security]], but also acknowledged the need for cooperation in addressing migration, as well as [[arms trafficking]].{{cite web|title=As Kelly and Tillerson Visit Mexico, Their Reassurances Differ From Trump's Stance|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/23/world/americas/john-kelly-rex-tillerson-mexico.html|work=[[New York Times]]|date=February 23, 2017|access-date=February 25, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Mexican officials tell US: We don't agree|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/23/politics/tillerson-kelly-mexico-statements/|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=February 23, 2017|access-date=February 25, 2017}} Tillerson recused himself from [[TransCanada Corporation|TransCanada]]'s application for a presidential permit for the proposed [[Keystone Pipeline|Keystone XL pipeline]].{{cite web |url=https://oge.app.box.com/v/TillersonRecusal|title=State Dept Response to Greenpeace 9 March 2017.pdf|website=oge.app.box.com|language=en-US|access-date=March 10, 2017}} Before the inauguration, Tillerson selected [[Elliott Abrams]] to be the [[United States Deputy Secretary of State]]. In February 2017, they held an interview with President Trump in the Oval Office. There, Tillerson contradicted the President's criticism of the [[Foreign Corrupt Practices Act]], advising Trump of Exxon's success in refusing a bribe demand by Yemen's oil minister. The next day, [[Fox News]] criticized Abrams, and Tillerson soon told Abrams he would not be nominated. [[File:Secretary Tillerson Meets With Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu (32063904794).jpg|thumb|Rex Tillerson with Israeli Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]]]] In mid-March 2017, Tillerson made his first trip to Asia, traveling to Japan, South Korea, and China.{{cite web|title=Secretary of State Tillerson To Travel to Tokyo, Seoul, and Beijing|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2017/03/268282.htm|publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]]|date=March 7, 2017|access-date=March 17, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Tillerson's quiet trip to Asia|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/03/rex-tillerson-asia-china-236059 |publisher=[[Politico]]|first=Michael|last=Crowley|date=March 15, 2017|access-date=March 17, 2017}} Tillerson remarked that diplomatic efforts in the past 20 years to stop North Korea's nuclear development had "failed". Tillerson also stated the United States may need to take preemptive action, remarking "Certainly, we do not want things to get to a military conflict ... but obviously, if North Korea takes actions that threatens the South Korean forces or our own forces, then that would be met with an appropriate response.
