If they elevate the threat of their weapons program to a level that we believe that requires action, that option is on the table."{{cite web|title=Rex Tillerson Rejects Talks With North Korea on Nuclear Program |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/17/world/asia/rex-tillerson-north-korea-nuclear.html?_r=0=|work=[[New York Times]]|date=March 17, 2017|access-date=March 17, 2017|last=Sanger|first=David}}{{cite web|title=Tillerson on North Korea: Military action is 'an option' |first1=James |last1=Griffiths |first2=Paula |last2=Hancocks |first3=Alexandra |last3=Field |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/17/politics/tillerson-south-korea-dmz/|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=March 17, 2017|access-date=March 17, 2017}} On March 30, 2017, Tillerson met with [[President of Turkey|President]] [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] of [[Turkey]]. Turkey has criticized the United States over its support for [[Rojava|Syrian Kurds]].{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-turkey-usa-idUSKBN1710WD |title=Tillerson tells frustrated Turks: U.S. faces tough choices in Syria |first1=Lesley |last1=Wroughton|first2=Ece |last2=Toksabay |publisher=Reuters|date=March 30, 2017}} In May, protestors and Erdoğan's bodyguards [[2017 clashes at the Turkish Ambassador's Residence in Washington, D.C.|clashed outside of the Turkish Ambassador's Residence in Washington, D.C.]] Tillerson said that the incident was "outrageous" and that the Trump administration has expressed "dismay" over it. He said the administration will await the outcome of an investigation before taking further action.{{Cite news|title=Tillerson waits on Turkey embassy brawl; McCain says 'look at the clip' |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/05/21/tillerson-waits-on-turkey-embassy-brawl-mccain-says-look-at-clip.html|date=May 21, 2017|publisher=[[Fox News]] |accessdate=May 22, 2017}} In mid-April 2017, Tillerson made his first trip to Russia as Secretary of State, meeting with [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Foreign Minister]] [[Sergey Lavrov]] and [[President of Russia|President]] [[Vladimir Putin]]. At a news conference, Tillerson remarked that [[Russia–United States relations|Russian-U.S. relations]] were at a "low point".{{cite web|title=Putin meets with Tillerson in Russia as Syria rift deepens |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/12/politics/russia-syria-tillerson/|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=April 12, 2017|access-date=April 17, 2017}}{{cite web |title=Tillerson says 'US-Russia relations at a low point' after meeting with Putin|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/Tillerson-meets-with-Putin-amid-tensions-over-Syria/story?id=46738628|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=April 12, 2017 |access-date=April 17, 2017|first=Conor|last=Finnegan}} Tillerson also warned Russia of the risk of "becoming irrelevant in the Middle East" by continuing to support Syrian President [[Bashar al-Assad]].{{cite web |title=Tillerson Warns Russia on Syria, Saying Assad Era Is 'Coming to an End'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/11/world/europe/russia-syria-rex-tillerson.html|work=[[New York Times]]|date=April 11, 2017|access-date=April 17, 2017|last=Harris|first=Gardiner}} [[File:Secretary Tillerson Poses for a Photo With Argentine President Macri (40098814991).jpg|thumb|left|Tillerson with Argentine President [[Mauricio Macri]] in [[Buenos Aires]], February 2018]] In May 2017, Tillerson joined Trump on the President's first overseas trip, with the first destination being [[Saudi Arabia]].{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-gets-elaborate-welcome-in-saudi-arabia-embarking-on-first-foreign-trip/2017/05/20/679f2766-3d1d-11e7-a058-ddbb23c75d82_story.html|title=Trump signs 'tremendous' deals with Saudi Arabia on his first day overseas|first1=Philip|last1=Rucker|first2=Karen|last2=DeYoung|date=May 20, 2017|accessdate=November 1, 2017|website=Washingtonpost.com}} While in Saudi Arabia, Tillerson held a joint press conference with Saudi Arabian Foreign Minister [[Adel al-Jubeir|Adel bin Ahmed Al-Jubeir]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rn0xaUZBCVg|title=Rex Tillerson Joint Press Conference in Saudi Arabia|first=|last=Rshill7|date=May 20, 2017|accessdate=November 1, 2017|publisher=[[YouTube]]}} In June 2017, Tillerson excluded [[Myanmar]], [[Iraq]], and [[Afghanistan]] from the list of countries that employ [[child soldiers]] in that year's [[Trafficking in Persons Report]], rejecting the unanimous recommendations of staff.{{cite news|last1=Baumgaertner|first1=Emily|title=Tillerson Accused of Violating Federal Law on Child Soldiers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/21/us/politics/tillerson-child-soldiers.html|accessdate=November 23, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 22, 2017|page=A11}} Staff then circulated a memo in their [[Dissent Channel]] alleging that Tillerson's decision was in violation of the [[Child Soldiers Prevention Act]].{{cite news|last1=Szep|first1=Jason|last2=Spetalnick|first2=Matt|title=U.S. diplomats accuse Tillerson of breaking child soldiers law|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-tillerson-childsoldiers/u-s-diplomats-accuse-tillerson-of-breaking-child-soldiers-law-idUSKBN1DL0EA|accessdate=November 23, 2017|work=[[Reuters]]|date=2017}} In late November 2017, the topic garned national attention when the State Department defended Tillerson's actions in the wake of an anonymous complaint by a State Department official to the State Department Inspector General and the distribution of supporting documents to the Inspector General and to the [[Senate Foreign Relations Committee]].[https://www.cbsnews.com/videos/did-secretary-of-state-tillerson-violate-child-soldiers-law/ "Did Secretary of State Tillerson violate child soldiers law?"], November 22, 2017, [[CBS News]], retrieved November 23, 2017[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/state-department-employees-split-with-tillerson-on-child-soldiers-list/2017/11/21/ea906b8b-6d72-4e88-bb57-197a38baf164_story.html State Department employees split with Tillerson on child-soldiers list], November 21, 2017, ''[[Washington Post]],'' retrieved November 23, 2017[http://www.newsweek.com/does-rex-tillerson-support-using-child-soldiers-sec-state-accused-violating-718039 "Does Rex Tillerson Support Using Child Soldiers?"], November 21, 2017, ''[[Newsweek]],'' retrieved November 23, 2017. President Trump's [[2018 United States federal budget]] sought to reduce the State Department's budget by 31%. Tillerson froze most hiring and sought to remove 2,000 career diplomats by offering them $25,000 buyouts. In June 2017, Tillerson told graduates of the [[Charles B. Rangel International Affairs Fellowship|Rangel]] and the [[Thomas R. Pickering Foreign Affairs Fellowship|Pickering Foreign Affairs Fellowship]]s that their offers to join the [[United States Foreign Service]] were rescinded and that they needed to repay the $85,000 scholarships or agree to work in temporary positions. Tillerson reversed that decision and allowed the graduates to become full [[Foreign Service Officer]]s after being asked to do so by 31 members of Congress.{{cite news|last1=Harris|first1=Gardiner|title=State Dept. Restores Job Offers to Students After Diplomat Outcry|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/30/us/politics/state-department-students-foreign-service.html|accessdate=November 23, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 1, 2017|page=A11}} Applications to take the Foreign Service entrance exam dropped 50% that year. Tillerson and his staff fired career ambassadors [[Patrick F. Kennedy]] and [[Kristie Kenney]], and attempted to remove [[Linda Thomas-Greenfield]], who then retired.{{cite news|last1=Harris|first1=Gardiner|title=Diplomats Sound the Alarm as They Are Pushed Out in Droves|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/24/us/politics/state-department-tillerson.html|accessdate=November 26, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 25, 2017|page=A1}} Tillerson selected [[Margaret Peterlin]] to be his [[Chief of Staff to the United States Secretary of State|Chief of Staff]].{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/biog/title/as/171315.htm|publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]]|title=Chief of Staff: Margaret Peterlin|access-date=April 14, 2017}}{{cite news |title=Tillerson’s Enigmatic Chief of Staff Wields Power, Not the Spotlight |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-05-31/tillerson-s-enigmatic-chief-of-staff-wields-power-not-spotlight |first=Nick |last=Wadhams |date=May 31, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170531154920/https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-05-31/tillerson-s-enigmatic-chief-of-staff-wields-power-not-spotlight |archive-date=May 31, 2017 |publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]}} Tillerson is reported to rely heavily on Peterlin, as well as his chief of policy, [[Brian Hook]].{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Eliana|last2=Crowley|first2=Michael|title=The bottleneck in Rex Tillerson’s State Department|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/06/04/rex-tillerson-state-department-bottleneck-239107|accessdate=June 4, 2017 |work=Politico|date=June 4, 2017}}{{cite news |title=Diplomats Question Tactics of Tillerson, the Executive Turned Secretary of State |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=August 7, 2017|page=A1 |first=Gardiner |last=Harris |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/06/us/politics/rex-tillerson-state-department.html}} Tillerson has attempted to centralize much decision making under the [[Policy Planning Staff (United States)|Policy Planning Staff]].{{cite news|last1=Gramer|first1=Robbie|last2=De Luce|first2=Dan|last3=Lynch|first3=Colum|title=How the Trump Administration Broke the State Department|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/07/31/how-the-trump-administration-broke-the-state-department/|accessdate=November 23, 2017|work=[[Foreign Policy]]|date=July 31, 2017}} Tillerson has initiated the [[Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review]], focusing on the State Department's [[organizational structure]].{{cite news|last1=Wadhams|first1=Nick|title=How Rex Tillerson Is Remaking the State Department|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-26/how-rex-tillerson-is-remaking-the-state-department|accessdate=November 23, 2017|work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]|date=October 26, 2017}} Tillerson contracted for [[management consulting]] from [[Deloitte]] and hired [[Insigniam]] to conduct a "listening tour" survey for $1 million.{{cite news|last1=Tracy|first1=Abigail|title=The State Department Is "Being Destroyed from Within"|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/08/rex-tillerson-state-department-reorganization|accessdate=November 23, 2017|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|date=August 20, 2017|language=en}} Tillerson has attempted to reduce inefficiencies within the [[United States Department of State|State Department]], though it has been described as a "botched reorganisation" that has created a hollowed out and dysfunctional department, reportedly leading to micromanaging and poor morale among career diplomats.{{cite news|author=|title=Rex Tillerson’s agonies|url=https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21730055-some-friction-between-president-and-secretary-state-normal-not-rex|work=[[The Economist]]|date=October 5, 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/08/04/why-has-rex-tillerson-belly-flopped-as-secretary-of-state/ |publisher=''[[Foreign Policy]]'' |title=Why Has Rex Tillerson Belly-Flopped as Secretary of State? |date=August 4, 2017 |access-date=August 7, 2017 |first=Derek |last=Chollet}} He has been praised for setting the right tone for diplomats.{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/the-administration/318098-secretary-of-state-rex-tillerson-sets-the-right-tone|title=Secretary of State Rex Tillerson sets the right tone for US diplomats|first=Kelsey|last=Rupp|date=February 6, 2017|website=Thehill.com|accessdate=November 1, 2017}} [[File:Secretary Tillerson Meets With Indian Prime Minister Modi in Washington (35421314671).jpg|thumb|Tillerson meets with Indian Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]], June 26, 2017]] [[File:Secretary Tillerson Greets Saudi King Salman Following the Saudi Arabia-Iraq Coordination Committee Meeting (37853939191).jpg|thumb|Tillerson greets King [[Salman of Saudi Arabia]], Riyadh, October 22, 2017]] Tillerson was reportedly angered by the political speech President Trump delivered at the [[2017 National Scout Jamboree]]. In October 2017, news reports surfaced regarding a deteriorating relationship between Tillerson and Trump. According to reports,{{Cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-wanted-dramatic-increase-nuclear-arsenal-meeting-military-leaders-n809701|title=Trump wanted dramatic increase in nuclear arsenal in military meeting|work=NBC News|access-date=October 14, 2017|language=en}} in a July 20 meeting, Trump suggested a ten-fold increase in the [[Nuclear weapons of the United States|United States nuclear arsenal]], which would cost trillions and take centuries,{{Cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/11/politics/tillerson-moron-comment/index.html|title=Tense and difficult meeting preceded Tillerson's 'moron' comment |last=CNN|first=Kevin Liptak, Dan Merica, Jeff Zeleny and Elise Labott,|work=CNN|access-date=October 14, 2017}} after which individuals familiar with the meeting told journalists that Tillerson either called Trump a "moron"{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/tillerson-s-fury-trump-required-intervention-pence-n806451|title=Tillerson's fury at Trump required an intervention from VP Pence|work=NBC News|access-date=October 14, 2017|language=en}} or a "fucking moron".{{Cite news |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/war_stories/2017/10/now_we_know_why_rex_tillerson_called_donald_trump_a_moron.html|title=Trump’s Nuclear Meltdown|last=Kaplan|first=Fred|date=October 11, 2017|work=Slate|access-date=October 14, 2017|language=en-US|issn=1091-2339}} Additionally, there were well-sourced reports of Tillerson offering to resign his office as [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]], only to be discouraged from doing so by [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Mike Pence]]; however, these were officially denied by both Tillerson and the White House.{{cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/10/rex-tillerson-donald-trump-state-department|first=Abigail|last=Tracy|title=Is 'Rexit' Looming?: Tillerson Is Throwing Off Trump's Shackles|magazine=Vanity Fair|date=October 3, 2017|access-date=November 27, 2017}} Furthermore, on October 1, Trump directly contradicted, via a public [[Twitter|tweet]], Tillerson's policy of negotiation with [[North Korea]];{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/914497877543735296|title=I told Rex Tillerson, our wonderful Secretary of State, that he is wasting his time trying to negotiate with Little Rocket Man...|last=Trump|first=Donald J.|date=October 1, 2017|website=@realDonaldTrump|language=en|access-date=October 14, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/914497947517227008|title=...Save your energy Rex, we'll do what has to be done!|last=Trump|first=Donald J.|date=October 1, 2017|website=@realDonaldTrump|language=en|access-date=October 14, 2017}} this move was widely panned by experts, who thought that such a public undermining of the chief [[diplomat]] of the [[United States]] would weaken Tillerson's ability to negotiate with other countries.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/save-your-energy-rex-trump-tweet-undermines-sec-state-tillerson-n806381|title='Save your energy, Rex': Trump tweet undermines Tillerson on N. Korea talks|work=NBC News|access-date=October 14, 2017|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/01/us/politics/trump-tillerson-north-korea.html|title=Trump Says Tillerson Is ‘Wasting His Time’ on North Korea|last=Baker|first=Peter|date=October 1, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=October 14, 2017|last2=Sanger|first2=David E.|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} On October 10, after Tillerson's alleged "moron" comment was reported in the media, Trump challenged Tillerson to "IQ tests",{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/10/10/trump-proposes-iq-tests-face-off-with-tillerson-after-secretary-of-state-calls-him-a-moron/|title=Trump proposes 'IQ tests' faceoff with Tillerson after secretary of state calls him a 'moron'|last=Rucker|first=Philip|date=October 10, 2017 |work=Washington Post|access-date=October 14, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} and three days later [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Bob Corker]] from [[List of United States Senators from Tennessee|Tennessee]], the [[Chairman|Chair]] of the influential [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|Senate Foreign Relations Committee]] who had become a vocal Trump critic around that time, remarked that Trump was "publicly castrating" Tillerson.{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/10/13/bob-corker-rex-tillerson-castrate-trump-243771|title=Corker unloads on Trump for trying to 'castrate' Tillerson|work=POLITICO|access-date=October 14, 2017}} In November 2017, Tillerson said that [[Rohingya persecution in Myanmar (2016–present)|recent Rohingya persecution in Myanmar]] was [[ethnic cleansing]].{{cite news|last1=Landler|first1=Mark|title=Myanmar's Crackdown on Rohingya Is Ethnic Cleansing, Tillerson Says|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/22/us/politics/tillerson-myanmar-rohingya-ethnic-cleansing.html|accessdate=November 23, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 23, 2017|page=A13}} Tillerson has made a concerted effort to respond to the State Department's backlog of [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] requests that reach into Secretary [[Hillary Clinton]]'s tenure, assigning midlevel diplomats from every bureau to perform [[document review]] aside unpaid interns. By the end of November 2017, 10 of the top 44 political positions in the State Department had been filled. A large number of [[Senior Foreign Service]] officers had resigned under Tillerson, with the number of career ambassadors and ministers dropping more than 50%, from 39 to 19, and the number of minister-counselors dropping 18% to 369. On March 13, 2018, Tillerson commented on the [[Poisoning of Sergei and Yulia Skripal|nerve gas poisoning in the United Kingdom of a former Russian spy and his daughter]], calling it a "really egregious act" that clearly "came from Russia".{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/tillerson-says-u-k-spy-poisoning-clearly-came-russia-n856056|title=Tillerson says U.K. spy poisoning 'clearly' came from Russia|last1=Williams|first1=Abigail|last2=Elbaum|first2=Rachel|date=March 13, 2018|work=NBC News|accessdate=March 13, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/rex-tillerson-nerve-agent-used-poison-ex-spy-clearly-came-from-russia/|title=Tillerson: Nerve agent used to poison ex-spy "clearly came from Russia"|date=March 12, 2018|work=CBS News|accessdate=March 13, 2018}} ==== Dismissal ==== According to the White House, Trump communicated with Tillerson on March 9 and told him he would be replaced.{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/378073-tillerson-ousted-as-secretary-of-state-report|title=Trump removes Tillerson at State|last=Savransky|first=Rebecca|date=March 13, 2018|work=TheHill|access-date=March 13, 2018|language=en}} Tillerson cut short a visit to Africa and returned to the United States on March 12. On March 13, Trump announced via a public [[Twitter|tweet]] that Tillerson was out.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/973540316656623616|title=[5:44 AM] Mike Pompeo, Director of the CIA, will become our new Secretary of State. He will do a fantastic job! Thank you to Rex Tillerson for his service! Gina Haspel will become the new Director of the CIA, and the first woman so chosen. Congratulations to all!|last=Trump|first=Donald J.|date=March 13, 2018|website=@realDonaldTrump|language=en|access-date=March 13, 2018}} A spokesman for Tillerson, [[Steve Goldstein (diplomat)|Steve Goldstein]] (the [[Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs|Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy]]), was quoted by the ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' that Tillerson did not know why he had been fired by Trump and only found out about his firing when he read Trump's tweet on the morning of March 13;[https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-ousts-tillerson-will-replace-him-as-secretary-of-state-with-cia-chief-pompeo/2018/03/13/30f34eea-26ba-11e8-b79d-f3d931db7f68_story.html Trump ousts Tillerson, will replace him as secretary of state with CIA chief Pompeo], Ashley Parker and Philip Rucker, ''[[Washington Post]]'', March 13, 2018. Goldstein, who was generally perceived within the White House as being anti-Trump,{{cite web|url=https://www.axios.com/state-departments-steve-goldstein-follows-tillerson-out-the-door-a05c25b3-ede0-4036-876f-a37295fc6e8b.html?source=sidebar|title="State Department Steve" fired after Tillerson ouster|website=Axios|language=en|access-date=March 13, 2018}} was fired by the White House later that day, reportedly for contradicting the official account of Tillerson's dismissal.{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/6b3fe76623e24c33ba17305a0e08c505|title=The Latest: Schumer says White House chaos hurts America|agency=Associated Press|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en-US}}{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-fires-top-tillerson-deputy-in-state-department-shake-up/|title=Trump fires Steve Goldstein, a top Tillerson deputy, in State Department shake-up|last=Atwood|first=Kylie|date=March 13, 2018|publisher=CBS News}} A senior Trump administration official cited "upcoming North Korea talks and various trade negotiations" as the reason for replacing Tillerson.{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/13/politics/rex-tillerson-secretary-of-state/index.html|title=Trump fires Tillerson, taps Pompeo as next secretary of state|authors=Nicole Gaouette, Kaitlan Collins and Dan Merica|publisher=CNN|date=March 13, 2018}} Trump later told reporters that his differences with Tillerson came down to personal chemistry and disagreements on policy, adding that he and Pompeo "have a very similar thought process".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-43388723|title=Trump fires Tillerson as secretary of state|date=March 13, 2018|publisher=BBC News}} ''The New York Times'' reported that Lebanese-American businessman [[George Nader (businessman)|George Nader]] turned Trump's major fundraiser [[Elliott Broidy]] "into an instrument of influence at the White House for the rulers of [[Saudi Arabia]] and the [[United Arab Emirates]]...High on the agenda of the two men...was pushing the White House to remove Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson"."[https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/21/us/politics/george-nader-elliott-broidy-uae-saudi-arabia-white-house-influence.html?mtrref=undefined&auth=login-email How 2 Gulf Monarchies Sought to Influence the White House]". ''The New York Times.'' 21 March 2018. [[John J. Sullivan (diplomat)|John Sullivan]], the [[United States Deputy Secretary of State|Deputy Secretary of State]], served as acting Secretary until March 31, when Tillerson formally left office.{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/378169-tillerson-says-commission-as-secretary-will-end-march-31|title=Tillerson says last day at State will be March 31|last=Greenwood|first=Max|date=March 13, 2018|work=The Hill}} Trump proposed [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] [[Director of the Central Intelligence Agency|Director]] [[Mike Pompeo]] (with whom Trump has a much more positive relationship) as Tillerson's successor and [[Gina Haspel]] as the new [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] [[Director of the Central Intelligence Agency|Director]]. Haspel was confirmed on May 17, 2018, making her the first female CIA director. Tillerson's total time in office was 423 days, making him the shortest-serving Secretary of State since [[Lawrence Eagleburger]] (1992–93). The last time a president's first appointee to the position served for less time was in 1898, when [[John Sherman]] left office after 413 days.{{cite news|url=http://editions.lib.umn.edu/smartpolitics/2018/03/18/rex-tillersons-historically-short-tenure-as-secretary-of-state/|title=Rex Tillerson’s Historically Short Tenure As Secretary of State|publisher=Smart Politics|date=March 18, 2018|author=Eric Ostermeier}} ==== Assessments of tenure ==== In March 2017, [[Robert Jervis]] of [[Columbia University]] wrote that Tillerson "had little impact on the Trump administration so far" and that his influence would continue to wane.{{cite web |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/03/10/rex-tillerson-might-be-the-weakest-secretary-of-state-ever/|title=Rex Tillerson Might Be the Weakest Secretary of State Ever|website=Foreign Policy|access-date=October 18, 2017}} That same month, [[William Inboden]] of the [[University of Texas at Austin]] defended Tillerson, saying that he deserves more time.{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/03/14/give-rex-tillerson-a-chance/|title=Give Rex Tillerson a Chance|website=Foreign Policy|first=Will|last=Inboden|date=March 14, 2017}} [[Daniel W. Drezner]] of the [[Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy]] at [[Tufts University]] was highly critical of Tillerson, calling him an "unmitigated disaster",{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/posteverything/wp/2017/10/18/the-sooner-rex-tillerson-resigns-as-secretary-of-state-the-better/|title=Perspective {{!}} The sooner Rex Tillerson resigns as secretary of state the better|last=Drezner|first=Daniel W.|date=October 18, 2017|work=Washington Post|access-date=October 18, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/posteverything/wp/2017/08/31/why-secretary-of-state-rex-tillerson-should-resign/|title=Perspective: Why Secretary of State Rex Tillerson should resign|last=Drezner|first=Daniel W.|date=August 31, 2017 |work=Washington Post|access-date=October 18, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} and "the most incompetent Secretary of State in modern history."{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/posteverything/wp/2018/03/13/five-thoughts-about-the-firing-of-rex-tillerson/|title=Perspective {{!}} Five thoughts about the firing of Rex Tillerson|last=Drezner|first=Daniel W.|date=March 13, 2018|work=Washington Post|access-date=March 13, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} Elliot Cohen of [[Johns Hopkins University]] said that Tillerson might be one of the weakest Secretaries of State in American history.{{Cite news|author=[[Mary Louise Kelly]] interview with Elliot Cohen|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/09/19/552006618/secretary-of-state-rex-tillerson-faces-a-new-onslaught-of-criticism|title=Secretary of State Rex Tillerson Faces a New Onslaught of Criticism|work=Morning Edition|publisher=NPR|date=September 19, 2017}} Elizabeth Saunders of [[George Washington University]] said that Tillerson's tenure had damaged the State Department "for a generation" and decreased America's ability to respond to major crisis. Tillerson's tenure as Secretary of State lasted 405 days, one of the [[List of United States Secretaries of State#List of Secretaries of State by time in office|shortest tenures in modern history]]. Tillerson is the shortest-serving Secretary since [[Lawrence Eagleburger]], who served during the last month of [[President of the United States|President]] [[George H. W. Bush]]'s term. Excluding Secretaries whose tenures were ended by the arrival of a new presidential administration, Tillerson is the shortest-serving Secretary since 1900.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2018/03/13/rex-tillerson-outlasted-15-other-secretaries-of-state-but-only-one-who-left-under-duress/|title=Rex Tillerson outlasted 15 other secretaries of state — but only one who left under duress|last=Bump|first=Philip|date=March 13, 2018|work=The Washington Post}} According to long-time diplomat [[Aaron David Miller]], Tillerson is also the only Secretary of State since at least 1945 to have been fired.{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/13/opinions/tillerson-firing-makes-head-explode-opinion-miller/index.html|title=Longtime diplomat: Tillerson's public firing makes my head explode|last=Miller|first=Aaron David|publisher=CNN|date=March 13, 2018}} == Political views == [[File:Secretary Tillerson Greets German Foreign Minister Gabriel Before Their Meeting in Washington (32631865426).jpg|thumb|Tillerson greets German Foreign Minister [[Sigmar Gabriel]], Washington, D.C., February 2, 2017]] In October 2017, ''Politico'' reported that Tillerson's major foreign policy positions include "urging the United States to stay in the [[Trans-Pacific Partnership]] and the [[Paris Agreement|Paris climate accord]], taking a hard line on Russia, advocating negotiations and dialogue to defuse the mounting crisis with North Korea, advocating for continued U.S. adherence to the [[Iran nuclear deal framework|Iran nuclear deal]], taking a neutral position in [[Qatar–Saudi Arabia proxy conflict|the dispute between Qatar and Saudi Arabia]], and reassuring jittery allies, from South Korea and Japan to our NATO partners, that America still has their back".Aaron David Miller and Richard Sokolsky, "Should Rex Tillerson Resign?", [http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2017/10/01/should-rex-tillerson-resign-215664 ''Politico'' October 1, 2017] === Russia and Saudi Arabia === In 2014, Tillerson expressed opposition to the [[International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis|sanctions against Russia]] in response to the [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation of Crimea]] at an Exxon shareholder meeting.{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/586ae5c0-487c-11e4-ad19-00144feab7de|title=Subscribe to read|work=Financial Times}} He told the meeting "We do not support sanctions, generally, because we don't find them to be effective unless they are very well implemented comprehensively and that's a very hard thing to do."{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/news/2016/12/06/exxon-ceo-tillerson-secretary-of-state.html|title=How Exxon CEO Tillerson feels about sanctions (and other Secretary-related matters)|publisher=Biz Journals|date=December 6, 2016}} In 2016, Tillerson said that the US should have deployed military units to neighboring states next to Russia in a more "muscular" response.{{cite web|author=Matthew Lee |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/russia-friend-sanctions-foe-tillerson-gets-hearing-081213134--election.html |title=Trump's pick for top diplomat takes tough line on Moscow|work=Yahoo|date=January 12, 2017|accessdate=January 25, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/jan/11/rex-tillerson-us-response-russia-crimea-seizure-wa/ |title=Rex Tillerson: U.S. response to Russia Crimea seizure was 'weak'|work=Washington Times |date=January 11, 2017|accessdate=January 25, 2017}} In 2017, Tillerson said that Russia's annexation of Crimea was illegal."[http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/jan/11/rex-tillerson-us-response-russia-crimea-seizure-wa/ Rex Tillerson takes tough line on Russian hacking in tense hearing]". ''The Washington Times''. January 11, 2017. He also compared China's controversial [[Great wall of sand|island-building]] in the [[Territorial disputes in the South China Sea|South China Sea]] to Russia's annexation of Crimea."[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-38607235 South China Sea: China media warn US over 'confrontation']". BBC News. January 13, 2017. [[File:Secretary Tillerson and Saudi Foreign Minister Adel Al-Jubeir Address Reporters in Washington (33480721801).jpg|thumb|Tillerson and Saudi Foreign Minister [[Adel al-Jubeir]], Washington, D.C., March 23, 2017]] During his Secretary of State confirmation hearings, [[Marco Rubio]] asked Tillerson if he would label [[Saudi Arabia]] as a "human rights violator". Tillerson declined to do so, saying: "When you designate someone or label someone, is that the most effective way to have progress be able to be made in Saudi Arabia or any other country?""[https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2017/live-updates/trump-white-house/confirmation-hearings-trump-speaks-and-vote-a-rama-analysis-and-updates/tillerson-saudi-arabia-isnt-a-human-rights-violator/ Tillerson won't label Saudi Arabia a human rights violator]". ''The Washington Post''. January 11, 2017. He supported the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen]]."[https://theintercept.com/2017/01/12/rex-tillerson-wants-to-provide-saudi-arabia-with-more-help-to-bomb-yemen/ Rex Tillerson Wants to Provide Saudi Arabia With More Help to Bomb Yemen]". ''The Intercept''. January 12, 2017. === Climate change and carbon tax === Tillerson announced in 2009 that ExxonMobil favored a [[carbon tax]] as "the most efficient means of [[Carbon pricing|reflecting the cost of carbon]] in all economic decisions—from investments made by companies to fuel their requirements to the product choices made by consumers".{{cite web|url=https://energyfactor.exxonmobil.com/corporate-citizenship-sustainability/exxonmobil-and-the-carbon-tax|title=ExxonMobil and the carbon tax|publisher=ExxonMobil.com|date=December 2, 2015}} In October 2016, less than two months before his nomination as Secretary of State, he reaffirmed that ExxonMobil believed a carbon tax would be "the best policy of those being considered. Replacing the hodge-podge of current, largely ineffective regulations with a revenue-neutral carbon tax would ensure a uniform and predictable cost of carbon across the economy ... allow market forces to drive solutions ... maximize transparency, reduce administrative complexity, promote global participation and easily adjust" to new knowledge in climate science and in the policy consequences of various courses of action.{{cite speech |title=The Path Forward in Today's Energy Environment |first=Rex |last=Tillerson |event=37th Annual Oil and Money Conference |location=London, England |date=October 19, 2016 |url=http://corporate.exxonmobil.com/en/company/news-and-updates/speeches/the-path-forward-in-todays-energy-environment |access-date=December 23, 2016}} An article in ''The New York Times'' suggested that ExxonMobil's embrace of a carbon tax in October 2009 may have simply been an effort to avoid [[Emissions trading|cap and trade]] legislation that was then being considered by the U.S. Congress as an alternative method of [[carbon pricing]].{{cite news |last=Schwartz |first=John |title=Tillerson Led Exxon's Shift on Climate Change; Some Say 'It Was All P.R.' |newspaper=The New York Times |date=December 28, 2016 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/28/business/energy-environment/rex-tillerson-secretary-of-state-exxon.html?_r=0 |access-date=December 30, 2016}} A ''Time'' magazine article in December 2016 asserted that since Tillerson announced his company's preference for a carbon tax, ExxonMobil "has not made a carbon tax a focus of its massive lobbying efforts and has supported a number of candidates and organizations that oppose measures to tackle the [climate change] issue".{{cite news |last=Worland |first=Justin |title=What Rex Tillerson as Secretary of State Would Mean for Climate Change |newspaper=Time |date=December 14, 2016 |url=http://time.com/4598499/rex-tillerson-donald-trump-exxon-mobil-climate-change/?xid=homepage |access-date=December 30, 2016}} In 2010, Tillerson said that while he acknowledged that humans were affecting the climate through greenhouse gas emissions to some degree, it was not yet clear "to what extent and therefore what can you do about it".{{cite web|url=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CHRG-111hhrg76003/pdf/CHRG-111hhrg76003.pdf|title=THE EXXONMOBIL-XTO MERGER: IMPACT ON U.S. ENERGY MARKETS |publisher=Gpo.gov |accessdate=December 11, 2016}}{{cite news|last=Schwartz|first=John|date=August 19, 2016|title=Exxon Mobil Fraud Inquiry Said to Focus More on Future Than Past|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/20/science/exxon-mobil-fraud-inquiry-said-to-focus-more-on-future-than-past.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=August 23, 2016}} In 2016, Tillerson stated, "The world is going to have to continue using fossil fuels, whether they like it or not."{{cite news|last=Schlanger|first=Zoe|title=Is Exxon Waiting for the Paris Climate Agreement to Fail?|url=http://www.newsweek.com/exxon-shareholders-climate-change-paris-agreement-463592|newspaper=[[Newsweek]]|date=May 26, 2016}} === Support for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) === [[File:President Xi Jinping Greets Secretary Tillerson (33139050550).jpg|thumb|Tillerson with [[China]]'s President [[Xi Jinping]] before their meeting in Beijing, March 19, 2017]] In 2013, Tillerson outlined his support for the [[Trans-Pacific Partnership]] (TPP), stating at the Global Security Forum: "One of the most promising developments on this front is the ongoing effort for the Trans-Pacific Partnership ... The 11 nations that have been working to lower trade barriers and end protectionist policies under this partnership are a diverse mix of developed and developing economies. But all of them understand the value of open markets to growth and progress for every nation."Betsy Woodruff, [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/12/12/trump-s-sec-of-state-favorite-rex-tillerson-praised-tpp.html "Trump's Secretary of State Favorite Rex Tillerson Praised TPP"], December 12, 2016, ''The Daily Beast''. [[File:Secretary Tillerson Meets with the South Korean and Japanese Foreign Ministers (35615478893).jpg|thumb|Tillerson, South Korean Foreign Minister [[Kang Kyung-wha]] and Japanese Foreign Minister [[Tarō Kōno]], August 7, 2017]] === Free trade === Speaking in March 2007 at a [[Council on Foreign Relations]] event, Tillerson said:
Should the United States seek so-called energy independence in an elusive effort to insulate this country from the impact of world events on the economy, or should Americans pursue the path of international engagement, seeking ways to better compete within the global market for energy? Like [[Members of the Council on Foreign Relations#Notable historical members|the Council's founders]], I believe we must choose the course of greater international engagement ... The central reality is this: The global free market for energy provides the most effective means of achieving U.S. energy security by promoting resource development, enabling diversification, multiplying our supply channels, encouraging efficiency, and spurring innovation.{{cite news|last=Denning|first=Liam|title=Mr. Exxon Goes to Washington (Maybe)|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/gadfly/articles/2016-12-07/rex-tillerson-secretary-of-state-what-it-would-mean|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|date=December 7, 2016}}
=== Government regulation === In 2012 in an interview with ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', Tillerson expressed his impatience with government regulation, stating "there are a thousand ways you can be told 'no' in this country."{{cite news|last=Coll|first=Steve|title=Gusher: The Power of ExxonMobil|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/04/09/gusher|work=The New Yorker|date=April 9, 2012}} [[File:Secretary Tillerson Shakes Hands with President Rodrigo Duterte (36027526740).jpg|thumb|left|Tillerson with Philippine President [[Rodrigo Duterte]] at [[Malacañang Palace]] in Manila, Philippines on August 7, 2017]] === Education === In September 2013, Tillerson wrote an [[op-ed]] piece in ''The Wall Street Journal'' defending [[Common Core]].{{cite web|last=Tillerson|first=Rex|title=How to Stop the Drop in American Education|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324747104579024892381188288|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=September 5, 2013}} === Republican campaign fundraising and donations === According to the [[Center for Responsive Politics]], Tillerson has made tens of thousands of dollars of political donations to Republican groups and candidates.{{cite web|last1=Mitchell|first1=Andrea|title=Rex Tillerson of ExxonMobil Expected to Be Named Trump's Secretary of State: Sources|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/rex-tillerson-exxon-mobile-expected-be-named-trump-s-secretary-n694371?cid=eml_nbn_20161210|publisher=[[NBC News]]|accessdate=December 10, 2016}} According to FEC records, he gave a total of $468,970 in contributions to Republican candidates and committees from 2000 to 2016.{{cite web|title=Rex Tillerson Political Campaign Contributions|url=http://www.campaignmoney.com/political/contributions/rex-tillerson.asp?cycle=16|website=Campaign Money|accessdate=January 25, 2017}} He has contributed to the political campaigns of [[George W. Bush]], as well as [[Mitt Romney]] in 2012, and [[Mitch McConnell]].{{cite web|url=http://archive.fortune.com/galleries/2012/fortune/1205/gallery.500-CEO-political-donations.fortune/2.html |title=Where CEO political dollars go – Rex Tillerson (2) |work=Fortune |accessdate=December 10, 2016}} He did not donate to Donald Trump's campaign. He donated to [[Jeb Bush]]'s campaign during the [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016|2016 Republican primaries]].{{cite web|last=Lavelle|first=Marianne|url=https://insideclimatenews.org/news/22072016/donald-trump-fossil-fuel-campaign-contributions-republican-oil-money|title=Fossil Fuel Money Still a Dry Well for Trump Campaign|publisher=InsideClimate News|date=July 22, 2016|accessdate=December 10, 2016}} == Personal life == [[File:Secretary Tillerson and Mrs. St. Clair Walk Through the State Department's Main Lobby on his First Day (32516939282).jpg|thumb|Tillerson and Renda St. Clair on February 1, 2017]] Rex Tillerson has been married twice. He divorced Jamie Lee Henry, his first wife, with whom he has twin boys.{{cite book|author=Steve Coll|title=Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American Power|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AipuCoT96yQC&pg=PT137|accessdate=April 2, 2017|date=May 1, 2012|publisher=Penguin Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-101-57214-6|page=137}} In 1986, Tillerson married Renda St. Clair, who has a son from her previous marriage. Tillerson also has a son, born in 1988, with St. Clair.{{cite web|url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/biography/S-Z/Tillerson-Rex-W-1952.html#b|title=Rex W. Tillerson biography|last=Cordon|first=Matthew C.|work=Encyclopedia of Business, 2nd ed. |accessdate= January 23, 2012}} Tillerson's twin sons are engineers and hold their bachelor's degrees from the [[Cockrell School of Engineering]] at the University of Texas at Austin.{{cite web|title=Tillerson Family Commits $5 Million to Cockrell School of Engineering, Bolsters Engineering Education and Research Center|url=https://news.utexas.edu/2014/04/15/tillerson-family-commits-5-million-to-cockrell-school|work=University of Texas|accessdate=April 2, 2017|date=April 15, 2014}} In 2006, Tillerson was named a Distinguished Engineering Graduate. Tillerson resides in [[Bartonville, Texas]].{{cite news|first=Candy |last=Evans|title=Rex Tillerson Bought the Late Charles Wyly's Equestrian Ranch in Argyle: Horse Country Just Got Hotter|url=http://candysdirt.com/2016/12/16/will-rex-tillersons-new-job-make-bartonville-even-hotter-horse-country/|accessdate=March 29, 2017|work=CandysDirt.com|date=December 16, 2016}} Following his appointment as Secretary of State, Tillerson bought a home in [[Kalorama, Washington, D.C.]]{{cite news|first=Benjamin |last=Freed|title=Rex Tillerson Buys $5.6 Million Kalorama Home|url=https://www.washingtonian.com/2017/02/22/rex-tillerson-buys-5-6-million-kalorama-home/|accessdate=April 21, 2017|work=Washingtonian|date=February 22, 2017}} He is a [[Congregationalist]] who holds a membership in the [[National Association of Congregational Christian Churches]], a [[mainline Protestant|mainline]] [[Reformed]] denomination.{{cite web|url=http://religionnews.com/2016/12/14/rex-tillerson-establishment-protestant-secretary-of-state/|title=Rex Tillerson, Establishment Protestant secretary of state|first=Mark|last=Silk|publisher=Religious News Service|date=December 14, 2016|accessdate=February 2, 2017}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AipuCoT96yQC|title=Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American Power|first=Steve|last=Coll|date=2012|publisher=Penguin|via=Google Books|page=569}} He and his wife donated between $5,000 and $10,000 to the denomination's ''The Congregationalist Magazine'' in 2012.{{cite journal| volume=165 |number=3 |url=http://congregationalist.org/maguploads/magazineissue_43_tc_sept_2013_webcomp.pdf |journal=The Congregationalist|date=September 2013 |page=7|title=Honor Roll of Distinguished Individual Donors}}{{cite web|url=http://congregationalist.org/Donations.aspx|title=Donations|work=The Congregationalist|accessdate=February 3, 2017}} On February 20, 2014, news outlets reported that Tillerson and his wife had joined opponents of a proposed water tower that could lead to fracking-related traffic near their homes. Plaintiffs included former U.S. House of Representatives Majority Leader [[Dick Armey]] and his wife.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/02/26/us-usa-fracking-tillerson-idUSBREA1P24O20140226 |title=Exxon Mobil CEO welcomes fracking, but not water tower in his backyard |first=Marice|last= Richter|work=Reuters|date=February 26, 2014}}{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304899704579391181466603804|title=Exxon CEO Joins Suit Citing Fracking Concerns|work=The Wall Street Journal |first=Daniel |last=Gilbert|date=February 20, 2014}} The Tillersons dropped out of the lawsuit after a judge dismissed their claim in November 2014.{{cite news |title=Rex Tillerson drops out of water tower lawsuit in Bartonville|first=Nicholas|last=Sakelaris |work=Dallas Business Journal|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/news/2014/04/21/rex-tillerson-dropsout-of-water-tower-lawsuit-in.html |date=April 21, 2014|accessdate=November 28, 2014}} In 2015, Tillerson was named as the 25th most powerful person in the world by ''[[Forbes]]''. On May 16, 2018, former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson gave a graduation speech at [[Virginia Military Institute]] and warned that there is "a growing crisis in ethics and integrity."{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/05/16/rex-tillerson-speech-ethics-591876 |title=Tillerson warns of ethical crisis among U.S. leaders in speech |author=Quint Forgey |date=May 16, 2018 |website=Politico.com |publisher= |access-date=May 17, 2018 |quote=}} "If our leaders seek to conceal the truth or we as people become accepting of alternative realities that are no longer grounded in facts, then we as American citizens are on a pathway to relinquishing our freedom."http://thehill.com/homenews/news/387971-tillerson-warns-of-growing-crisis-in-ethics-and-integrity-in-commencement == See also == *[[List of Secretaries of State of the United States]] *[[List of foreign ministers in 2017]] *[[List of people and companies named in the Paradise Papers]] == Notes == {{Notelist}} == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * {{cite book|title=Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American Power|last1=Coll|first1=Steve|author-link1=Steve Coll|publisher=Penguin|year=2012|ISBN=978-1-59420-335-0}} == External links == {{Commons category|Rex Tillerson}} {{wikiquote}} * {{Britannica|1459891|Rex W. Tillerson}} * [https://www.state.gov/secretary/20172018tillerson/bio/index.htm Secretary of State] biography * [https://www.forbes.com/profile/rex-tillerson/ Rex Tillerson at ''Forbes''] * {{C-SPAN|rextillerson}} * [https://www.state.gov/secretary/20172018tillerson/index.htm Secretary of State Archive] {{s-start}} {{s-bus}} {{s-bef|before=[[Lee Raymond]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Chief Executive Officer of [[ExxonMobil]]|years=2006–2016}} {{s-aft|after=[[Darren Woods]]}} |- {{s-npo|bsa}} {{s-bef|before=[[John Gottschalk]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of national presidents of the Boy Scouts of America|President of the Boy Scouts of America]]|years=2010–2012}} {{s-aft|after=[[Wayne M. Perry]]}} |- {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[John Kerry]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[United States Secretary of State]]|years=2017–2018}} {{s-aft|after=[[Mike Pompeo]]}} {{s-end}} {{USSecState}} {{Trump cabinet}} {{ExxonMobil}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tillerson, Rex Wayne}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:20th-century Congregationalists]] [[Category:21st-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century American diplomats]] [[Category:21st-century American politicians]] [[Category:21st-century Congregationalists]] [[Category:American businesspeople in the oil industry]] [[Category:American chairmen of corporations]] [[Category:American chief executives of energy companies]] [[Category:American chief executives of Fortune 500 companies]] [[Category:American civil engineers]] [[Category:American Congregationalists]] [[Category:American diplomats]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Texas]] [[Category:Directors of ExxonMobil]] [[Category:Distinguished Eagle Scouts]] [[Category:ExxonMobil people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the United States National Academy of Engineering]] [[Category:National Executive Board of the Boy Scouts of America members]] [[Category:People from Wichita Falls, Texas]] [[Category:Petroleum politics]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Friendship]] [[Category:Texas Republicans]] [[Category:Trump administration cabinet members]] [[Category:United States Secretaries of State]] [[Category:University of Texas at Austin alumni]]

{{short description|South Korean shipbuilding company}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox company| | name = Samsung Heavy Industries | logo = Samsung Heavy Industries logo (english).svg | logo_size = 250px | type = [[Public Company|Public]] | traded_as = {{kse|010140}} | caption = | foundation = {{start date and age|1974|08|05}} | location = [[Samsung Town]], [[Seoul]], South Korea | key_people = Joon Ou Nam : President and CEO | owner = [[Samsung Electronics]] 17.62%
[[National Pension Service]] 5.04%
Korea Investment and Securities 5.00% (as of 18 July 2011){{cite web|url=http://stock.daum.net/item/company.daum?code=010140&type=41 |title=Daum stock data: Samsung Heavy Industries|publisher=Daum.net |language=Korean |accessdate=18 July 2011}} | industry = [[Engineering]]
[[Naval architecture|Naval engineering]]
[[Shipbuilding]] | products = [[Ship]]s, [[Offshore plant]], [[Wind power]], [[Electric power & control systems]] and [[Engineering & Infrastructure]] | revenue = [[US$]] 8.58 billion (2015){{cite web |title=Samsung Heavy Industries Co., Ltd. |publisher=Nikkei Asian Review |url=http://asia.nikkei.com/Company/05HXS4-E}} | net_income = [[US$]] {{color |red| (1.06)}} billion (2015) | assets = [[US$]] 14.8 billion (2015) | equity = [[US$]] 3.6 billion (2015) | num_employees = 11,897{{cite web|url=http://www.shi.samsung.co.kr/eng/|title=Welcome to Samsung Heavy Industries|publisher=}} (December 2016) | parent = [[Samsung]]| | website = http://www.samsungshi.com/Eng/default.aspx
http://www.samsungshi.com/kor/default.aspx | homepage = [http://www.shi.samsung.co.kr/eng/ Samsung Heavy Industries] }} '''Samsung Heavy Industries''' ([[Korean language|Korean]]: 삼성중공업) is one of the largest [[shipbuilder]]s in the world and one of the "Big Three" shipbuilders of South Korea (including [[Hyundai Heavy Industries|Hyundai]] and [[Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering|Daewoo]]). Goeje (in [[Gyeongsangnam-do]]) is one of the largest shipyards in the world, having 3 dry docks, and 5 floating docks. A core subsidiary of the [[Samsung Group]], South Korea's largest [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerate]], SHI's main focus is on the engineering, procurement, construction, commissioning and the delivery of: transportation ships for the commercial industry, topsides modules, drilling and floating production units for the oil and gas sector, [[gantry crane]]s for fabrication yards, digital instrumentaton and control devices for ships, and other construction and engineering services. SHI operates manufacturing facilities at home and abroad, including ship block fabrication factories in [[Ningbo]] and [[Rongcheng, Shandong|Rongcheng]], China. The Geoje Shipyard in particular, SHI's largest shipyard in South Korea, boasts the highest dock turnover rate in the world. The largest of the three docks, Dock No. 3, is {{convert|640|m|ft}} long, {{convert|97.5|m|ft}} wide, and {{convert|13|m|ft}} deep. Mostly ultra-large ships are built at this dock, having the world's highest production efficiency with yearly dock turnover rate of 10 and the launch of 30 ships per year.{{cite web|url=http://www.shi.samsung.co.kr/eng/company/06_01.asp|title=::: Samsung Heavy Industries :::|website=www.shi.samsung.co.kr}} SHI specializes in the building of high added-value and special purpose vessels, including [[LNG]] carriers, off-shore related vessels, oil drilling ships, FPSO/FSO's, ultra Large container ships and Arctic shuttle tankers. In recent times SHI has concentrated on LNG tankers and drillships. == History == Samsung Heavy Industries was established in 1974, when the company's Changwon plant was opened. SHI soon purchased Woojin, followed by the construction of Geoje shipbuilding facilities and merger with Daesung Heavy Industries. Samsung Shipbuilding and Daesung Heavy Industries were merged under Samsung Heavy Industries in 1983. Since then, it has put efforts in the introduction of new technologies and development of products, while expanding the business area into heavy equipment and construction. Since the 21st century, SHI began to build LNG and large passenger ships in earnest, and exported shipbuilding technologies to the United States. Samsung Heavy Industries decided to advance into the cruise ship market, the last remaining stronghold of EU shipbuilders. The company stated entering the undertaking was necessary to maintain its number one position in the global shipbuilding market.{{cite news|title=SHI Opens an Era of Cruise Shipbuilding in Korea|url=http://www.shi.samsung.co.kr/Eng/pr/news_view.aspx?Page=2&Seq=764&mac=f3adec1bf288896a0c9d440b2b8b531b|accessdate=11 January 2015|publisher=Samsung Heavy Industries|date=2 December 2009}} In 2009, SHI was contracted to build a new residential cruise ship named [[Utopia (cruise ship)|Utopia]], which will be the largest passenger ship ever assembled in Asia. The ship will test the waters by 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/12/01/asia-biggest-cruise-ship-lifestyle-travel-samsung.html?feed=rss_asia|title=A Cruise That Never Ends|work=Forbes|date=1 December 2009|accessdate=1 March 2010|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20120918111443/http://www.forbes.com/2009/12/01/asia-biggest-cruise-ship-lifestyle-travel-samsung.html?feed=rss_asia|archivedate=18 September 2012|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} ===Vehicle production=== Starting in the late 1980s, SHI produced [[forklift]]s and [[heavy equipment]] (mainly [[excavator]]s) at Changwon.{{cite web |url=http://www.samsung.com/us/news/newsPreviewRead.do?news_seq=141 |title=Construction Equipment Division of Samsung Heavy Industries Signs Letters of Intent with Volvo Construction Equipment and Clark Material Handling |publisher=Samsung |date=19 February 1998 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160611220914/http://www.samsung.com/us/news/newsPreviewRead.do?news_seq=141 |archivedate=11 June 2016 |deadurl=no}}{{cite book |last=Yun |first=Mikyung |editor1-first=Stephan |editor1-last=Haggard |editor2-first=Wonhyuk |editor2-last=Lim |editor3-first=Euysung |editor3-last=Kim |title=Economic Crisis and Corporate Restructuring in Korea: Reforming the Chaebol |year=2003 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |chapter=Foreign Direct Investment after the Crisis |isbn=978-0-521-82363-0 |page=255 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=aZW7QgZVlEUC&pg=PA255&lpg=PA255&dq=Samsung+Volvo+1998#v=onepage&q=Samsung%20Volvo%201998&f=false}} The forklift production was established through agreements with [[Clark Material Handling Company]] (production started in 1986) and the heavy equipment production came from the construction equipment division of Korea's Heavy Industries and Construction, acquired by Samsung in 1983 (SHI began manufacturing heavy equipment in 1987).{{cite web |url=https://www.kdevelopedia.org/download.do?timeFile=/mnt/idas/asset/2012/02/10/DOC/PDF/04201202100000703073301.pdf&originFileName=000000004981.pdf. |last=Kwon |first=Ki-Yul |title=A study on cross-border M&A and FDI policy in Korea |publisher=kdevelopedia.org |page=33 |accessdate=9 October 2017}} Truck production was added in May 1993.{{cite web |url=http://www.samsung.com/common/aboutsamsung/download/performance/group_ar_1996.pdf |title=Annual Report 1996 |publisher=Samsung |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403111054/http://www.samsung.com/common/aboutsamsung/download/performance/group_ar_1996.pdf |archivedate=3 April 2015 |page=59 |deadurl=no}} The company also assembled electric car prototypes.{{cite web |url=http://www.autonews.com/article/19940620000100/ANA/406200750?template=print1 |last=Gadacz |first=Oles |title=Samsung introduces its 1st car an electric |publisher=Automotive News |date=20 June 1994 |accessdate=11 June 2016}} The truck production business was spun off in 1996 as a separate company called [[Samsung Commercial Vehicles]].{{cite web |url=http://response.jp/article/2000/12/12/6063.html |script-title=ルノーは日産ディーゼルをこうする!? ---サムソン商用車の末路 |trans-title=Will Renault do the same with Nissan Diesel!? Samsung Commercial Vehicles ends |language=Japanese |publisher=Response.jp |date=12 December 2000 |accessdate=8 June 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160419160746/http://response.jp/article/2000/12/12/6063.html |archivedate=19 April 2016 |deadurl=no}}{{cite book |last=Whitby |first=David R. |editor1-first=Leslie R. |editor1-last=Rudnick |editor2-first=Ronald L. |editor2-last=Shubkin |title=Synthetic Lubricants And High-Performance Functional Fluids, Revised And Expanded |year=1999 |publisher=CRC Press |chapter=Automotive Trends in Asia |isbn=978-0-8247-0194-9 |page=730 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=vkYCvwxyvsIC&pg=PA730&lpg=PA730&dq=Samsung+Commercial+Vehicles+2000#v=onepage&q=Samsung%20Commercial%20Vehicles%202000&f=false}}{{cite web |url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=1881908 |title=Truck Firm Files For Bankruptcy |last=Hong |first=Gweon-sam |work=koreajoongangdaily.joins.com |publisher=JoongAng Ilbo |date=24 November 2000 |accessdate=15 September 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217223926/http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=1881908 |archivedate=17 December 2014 |deadurl=no}} The forklift and heavy equipment businesses were sold off in 1998. ===Wind Turbine Manufacture=== Samsung Heavy Industries has been involved in wind turbine manufacture including the S7.0-171 turbine, which in 2013 was the world's largest wind turbine {{cite web|title=Securing the World's Largest Wind Turbine|url=https://www.renewableenergyworld.com/articles/2013/10/securing-the-worlds-largest-wind-turbine.html|accessdate=22 September 2018}}{{cite web|title=The world's 10 biggest wind turbines|url=https://www.power-technology.com/features/featurethe-worlds-biggest-wind-turbines-4154395/|accessdate=22 September 2018}}. It is still one of the [[List of most powerful wind turbines|most powerful turbines]] on Earth. == See also == * [[Economy of South Korea]] * [[List of Korean companies]] * [[List of Korea-related topics]] * [[List of shipbuilders and shipyards]] * [[Seocho Samsung Town]] * [[Samsung Heavy Industries Rugby Club]] == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == *[http://www.samsungshi.com/Eng/default.aspx '''Samsung Heavy Industries''' website] (in English) *http://www.samsungshi.com/kor/default.aspx * [http://www.shipcs.co.kr/ Samsung Heavy Industries, Power & Control Systems Division website] * [http://www.samsung.com Samsung Global website] {{Samsung Group}} {{KRX 100 companies}} [[Category:Samsung subsidiaries|Heavy Industries]] [[Category:Shipbuilding companies of South Korea]] [[Category:Wind turbine manufacturers]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in Seoul]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1974]] [[Category:Vehicle manufacturing companies established in 1974]] [[Category:1974 establishments in South Korea]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Korea Stock Exchange]] [[Category:South Korean brands]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
{{coord|36|8|14|N|137|52|58|E|display=title}} [[Image:Power Grid of Japan as of 2008.png|right|thumb|Location of Shin Shinano and Japan's two utility frequencies]]
{{nihongo|'''Shin Shinano'''|新信濃変電所|Shin Shinano Hendensho}} is the designation of a [[Back-to-back connection#Power transmission|back-to-back]] [[high-voltage direct current]] (HVDC) facility in [[Japan]] which forms one of four [[frequency changer|frequency converter stations]] that link Japan's western and eastern power grids. The other three stations are at [[Higashi-Shimizu Frequency Converter|Higashi-Shimizu]], [[Minami-Fukumitsu]] and [[Sakuma Dam#HVDC frequency converter|Sakuma Dam]].
==Converter equipment== The HVDC back-to-back facility Shin Shinano uses line-commutated [[thyristor]] converters. The station houses two converters, one of which opened in December 1977,<ref>Compendium of HVDC schemes, [[International Council on Large Electric Systems|CIGRÉ]] Technical Brochure No. 003, 1987, pp100–103.</ref> the other in 1992. The original 1977 converter was one of the first thyristor-based HVDC schemes to be put into operation in the world and used oil-insulated, oil-cooled outdoor [[thyristor valve]]s supplied by [[Hitachi]] (60 Hz end) and [[Toshiba]] (50 Hz end). A special workshop was provided on the site, in which valve maintenance (for example replacing failed thyristors) could be carried out under clean conditions in order to avoid contamination of the oil.
The 1992 converter uses more conventional air-insulated, water-cooled thyristor valves. In 2008 the original 1977 converter was decommissioned and replaced by a third converter, similar in design to the 1992 converter but using [[thyristor#Light triggered thyristor|Light-Triggered Thyristors]].
The Shin-Shinano link operates with a dc link voltage of 125 kV for each converter. The station was initially rated at 300 MW. In 1992, with the addition of the second 300 MW converter, the maximum transferable power was uprated to 600 MW.
==See also== *[[Energy in Japan]] *[[Kii Channel HVDC system]] *[[HVDC Hokkaido–Honshu]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051115122606/http://www.transmission.bpa.gov/cigresc14/Compendium/SHINSHIN.htm www.transmission.bpa.gov/cigresc14/Compendium/SHINSHIN.htm] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051115122606/http://www.transmission.bpa.gov/cigresc14/Compendium/Shinshin%20Pictures.pdf www.transmission.bpa.gov/cigresc14/Compendium/Shinshin%20Pictures.pdf]
==External links== * [http://b4.cigre.org/Publications/Other-Documents CIGRÉ B4 Compendium of HVDC Schemes, 2009.] * [http://www.tepco.co.jp/ir/kojin/supply/transformation-j.html Substations of the Tokyo Electric Power Company] {{ja}}

revision.text:
'''Solar–hydrogen energy cycle''' is an energy cycle where a [[solar energy|solar]] powered [[electrolyzer]] is used to convert water to [[hydrogen]] and [[oxygen]]. Hydrogen and oxygen produced thus are stored to be used by a [[fuel cell]] to produce electricity when no sunlight is available.<ref name=lab>{{cite web|url=http://www.schatzlab.org/projects/real_world/schatz_solar.html|title=Schatz Solar Hydrogen Project|publisher=schatzlab.org|accessdate=2011-06-18|work=}}</ref>
==Working== [[Photovoltaic panel]]s convert sunlight to electricity. In this cycle, the excess electricity produced after consumption by devices connected to the system, is used to power an [[electrolyzer]]. The electrolyzer converts water into hydrogen and oxygen, which is stored. This hydrogen is used up by a [[fuel cell]] to produce electricity, which can power the devices when sunlight is unavailable.<ref name=lab/>
==Features== The Solar–Hydrogen energy cycle can be incorporated using [[Thin film solar cell#Organic solar cells|organic thin film solar cell]]s<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nakato|first1=Y.|last2=Jia|first2=G.|last3=Ishida|first3=M.|last4=Morisawa|first4=K.|last5=Fujitani|first5=M.|last6=Hinogami|first6=R.|last7=Yae|first7=S. |date=10 June 1998 |title=Efficient Solar-to-Chemical Conversion by One Chip of n-Type Silicon with Surface Asymmetry|journal=Electrochem. Solid-State Lett.|volume=1|issue=2|pages=71–73|publisher=[[Electrochemical Society]]|doi=10.1149/1.1390640|url=http://scitation.aip.org/getabs/servlet/GetabsServlet?prog=normal&id=ESLEF6000001000002000071000001&idtype=cvips&gifs=yes&ref=no|location=[[Osaka]], [[Japan]]|accessdate=2011-07-20}}</ref> and [[microcrystalline silicon]] [[thin film solar cell]]s<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yae|first1=Shinji|last2=Kobayashi|first2=Tsutomu|last3=Abe|first3=Makoto|last4=Nasu|first4=Noriaki|last5=Fukumuro|first5=Naoki|last6=Ogawa|first6=Shunsuke|last7=Yoshida|first7=Norimitsu|last8=Nonomura|first8=Shuichi|last9=Nakato|first9=Yoshihiro|last10=Matsuda|first10=Hitoshi |date=15 February 2007 |title=Solar to chemical conversion using metal nanoparticle modified microcrystalline silicon thin film photoelectrode|journal=Solar Energy Materials and Solar Cells|volume=91|issue=4|pages=224–229|publisher=[[ScienceDirect]]|doi=10.1016/j.solmat.2006.08.010|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S092702480600362X|location=[[Japan]]|accessdate=2011-07-20}}</ref> This cycle can also be incorporated using [[Photoelectrochemical cell|photoelectrochemical solar cells]]. These solar have been incorporated since 1972<ref name=spie>{{cite web|url=http://spie.org/x8413.xml?ArticleID=x8413|title=Water splitting to produce solar hydrogen using silicon thin film|publisher=spie.org|accessdate=2011-08-30|work=}}</ref> for hydrogen production<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fujishima|first1=Akira|last2=Honda|first2=Kenichi |date=7 July 1972 |title=Electrochemical Photolysis of Water at a Semiconductor Electrode|journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]|volume=238|issue=1|pages=37–38|publisher=[[Nature Publishing Group]]|doi=10.1038/238037a0|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v238/n5358/abs/238037a0.html|location=[[Japan]]|accessdate=2011-07-20 |pmid=12635268}}</ref> and is capable of directly converting sunlight into chemical energy.<ref name=spie/>
==Use of hydrogen iodide== An [[aqueous solution]] of [[hydrogen iodide]] has been proposed as an alternative to water as a fuel that can be used in this cycle. Splitting of hydrogen iodide is easier than splitting water as its [[Gibbs free energy change|Gibbs energy change]] for decomposition is lesser. Hence silicon photoelectrodes can decompose hydrogen iodide into hydrogen and iodine without any external bias.<ref name=spie/>
==Advantages== * This cycle is pollution free as the only effluent from this cycle is pure water.<ref name=lab/>
==See also== *[[Energy storage]] *[[Photocatalytic water splitting]] *[[Power to gas]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Solar-hydrogen energy cycle}} [[Category:Thermodynamic cycles]] [[Category:Hydrogen production]]

If an aircraft in flight suffers a disturbance in pitch that causes an increase (or decrease) in [[angle of attack]], it is desirable that the aerodynamic forces on the aircraft cause a decrease (or increase) in angle of attack so that the disturbance does not cause a continuous increase (or decrease) in angle of attack. This is [[longitudinal static stability]]. ''Static margin'' is a concept used to characterize the static longitudinal stability and controllability of aircraft and missiles. In aircraft analysis, static margin is defined as the distance between the center of gravity and the neutral point of the aircraft, expressed as a percentage of the mean aerodynamic chord of the wing. The greater this distance and the narrower the wing, the more stable the aircraft. Conventionally, the neutral point is aft of the c.g., although in rare cases (computer controlled fighter aircraft) it may be forward of the c.g., i.e. slightly unstable, to obtain quickness of response in combat. Too great longitudinal stability makes the aircraft "stiff" in pitch, resulting in such undesirable features as difficulty in obtaining the necessary stalled nose-up pitch when landing. The position of the neutral point is found by taking the algebraic net moment of all horizontal surfaces, measured from the nose of the aircraft, in the same manner as the c.g. is determined, i.e. the sum of all such moments divided by their total area. The stabilizer and elevator dominate this result, but it is necessary to account for all surfaces such as fuselage, landing gear, prop-normal, etc. It is also necessary to take account of the center of pressure of the wing, which can move a good deal fore and aft as angle of attack of a flat-bottom wing section (Clark Y) changes, or not at all in the case of self-stabilizing sections such as the M6. The neutral point in conventional aircraft is a short distance behind the c.g. ("The feathers of the arrow must be at the back"); but in unconventional aircraft such as canards and those with dual-wings, such as the Quickie, this will not be so. The overall rule stated above must hold, i.e. the neutral point must be aft of the c.g., wherever that may be. The position of the center of gravity is determined by factors such as the positions of loads, e.g. passengers, fuel, weapons, etc.; whether such loads can vary, e.g. presence or absence of luggage, ammunition, etc.; and how fuel is consumed during flight. Additional information regarding the usual position of the neutral point aft of the center of gravity is at [[longitudinal static stability]]. [http://www.boeing.com/commercial/aeromagazine/aero_02/textonly/fo01txt.html Effect of CG on handling of swept-wing airplanes] (For an aircraft this may be described as positive static margin.) The response of an aircraft or missile to an angular disturbance such as a [[Tait-Bryan angles|pitch]] disturbance is determined by its static margin. In missile analysis, static margin is defined as the distance between the center of gravity and the [[Center of pressure (fluid mechanics)|center of pressure]]. Missiles are symmetric vehicles and if they have airfoils they too are symmetric. For missiles, positive static margin implies that the complete vehicle makes a restoring moment for any angle of attack from the trim position. If the [[center of pressure (fluid mechanics)|center of pressure]] is behind the center of gravity then the moment will be restoring. For missiles with symmetric airfoils, the neutral point and the center of pressure are coincident and the term neutral point is not used. == Relationship to aircraft and missile stability and control== * If the center of gravity (CG) of an aircraft is forward of the neutral point, or the CG of a missile is forward of the center of pressure, the vehicle will respond to a disturbance by producing an aerodynamic moment that returns the [[angle of attack]] of the vehicle towards the angle that existed prior to the disturbance. * If the CG of an aircraft is behind the neutral point, or the CG of a missile is behind the center of pressure, the vehicle will respond to a disturbance by producing an aerodynamic moment that continues to drive the angle of attack of the vehicle further away from the starting position. The first condition above is positive static stability. In missile analysis this is described as positive static margin. (In aircraft analysis it may be described as negative static margin.)
The second condition above is negative static stability. In missile analysis this is defined as negative static margin. (In aircraft analysis it may be described as positive static margin.) Depending on the static margin, humans may not be able to use control inputs to the elevators to control the pitch of the vehicle. Typically, computer based [[autopilot]]s are required to control the vehicle when it has negative static stability - usually described as negative static margin. The purpose of the reduced stability (low static margin) is to make an aircraft more responsive to pilot inputs. An aircraft with a large static margin will be very stable and slow to respond to the pilot inputs. The amount of static margin is an important factor in determining the handling qualities of an aircraft. For an unguided rocket, the vehicle must have a large positive static margin so the rocket shows minimum tendency to diverge from the direction of flight given to it at launch. In contrast, guided missiles usually have a negative static margin for increased maneuverability. == See also == * [[Aerodynamic center]] * [[Longitudinal static stability]] * [[Center of pressure (fluid mechanics)|Center of pressure]] == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Static Margin}} [[Category:Aerospace engineering]] [[Category:Aerodynamics]]

Keenan | distributor = [[GoDigital Media Group]] | released = {{Film date|2012|06|19}} | runtime = 90 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Big Fix''''' is a 2012 [[documentary film]] about two filmmakers, Josh and Rebecca Tickell, as they travel along the coast of the [[Gulf of Mexico]] meeting the residents whose lives were changed by the [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill|''Deepwater Horizon'' oil spill]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thebigfixmovie.com/ |title=The shocking true story behind the BP oil spill |publisher=The Big Fix Movie |date=2012-01-27 |accessdate=2016-07-31}} The film argues that [[BP]] has utilized the oil dispersant [[Corexit]] in the Gulf to create the illusion that the [[Louisiana]] beaches are safe and the water (and seafood) uncontaminated. ==Participants== * [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]] * [[Jeff Goodell]] *[[Chris Hedges]] * [[Bobby Jindal]] * [[David Korten]] * [[Omar Mateen]]{{cite news|last1=Mauney |first1=Matt|title=2012 documentary shows Omar Mateen working security during BP oil spill|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/pulse-orlando-nightclub-shooting/os-omar-mateen-security-oil-spill-story.html|accessdate=June 15, 2016|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=June 15, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ExIhb5GEqWA|title=The Big Fix|publisher=A YouTube video clip was used for purposes of discussion to establish the man's identity}}{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1712088/documentary-footage-shows-omar-mateen-in-2010|title=Documentary Footage Shows Omar Mateen In 2010|publisher=Sky News|date=2016-06-15}} * [[Jim McDermott]] * Ed Overton ==Festivals and awards== {{refimprove|section|date=June 2016}} *Official Selection – Cannes Film Festival{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.fr/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/11172506.html |title=THE BIG FIX - Festival de Cannes (International Film Festival) |website=Festival-cannes.fr |date=2010-04-22 |accessdate=2016-07-31}} (The Big Fix was the only US documentary chosen as an Official Selection at the Cannes Film Festival in 2011.) *Winner, Best Documentary – [[Italian Environmental Film Festival]] *Winner, Best Documentary – International Water and Film Festival *Opening Night Movie – New Orleans Film Festival *Official Selection – Durban Film Festival *Official Selection – Best of Fest – IDFA *Official Selection – Rio de Janeiro Film Festival *Official Selection – Boulder International Film Festival *Official Selection – Sedona Film Festival *Official Selection – DC Environmental Film Festival *Official Selection – Hawaii International Film Festival *Official Selection – Tallahassee Film Festival *Official Selection – Bergen International Film Festival ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official|http://www.thebigfixmovie.com/}} * [http://www.greenplanet3d.com/ Green Planet Productions] * {{IMDb title|1939753}} * {{rottentomatoes|the_big_fix}} * {{metacritic film|the-big-fix}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Big Fix, The}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:2012 films]] [[Category:Documentary films about water and the environment]] [[Category:Deepwater Horizon oil spill]] [[Category:Documentary films about petroleum]] [[Category:Films directed by Josh Tickell]] {{environment-documentary-film-stub}}

[[Image:Wcst.png|thumb|righ|WCST Logo]] The '''Wildlife Conservation Society of Tanzania''' (WCST) is an independent, membership and non-profit making organization founded in 1988 in [[Tanzania]]. Its main objective is to assist the government in conserving flora, fauna and the environment within Tanzania.
== See also == *[[Uluguru bushshrike]]
